An antidote for chicken pox has been developed, but researchers warn that its widespread use could be dangerous, despite the fact that this drug has no serious side effects and is currently very effective at limiting the duration and severity of chicken pox.
Which one of the following, if true, helps most to reconcile the apparent discrepancy indicated above?
(A)The drug is extremely expensive and would be difficult to make widely available.
(B)The drug has to be administered several times a day, so patient compliance is likely to be low.
(C)The drug does not prevent the spread of chicken pox from one person to another, even when the drug eventually cures the disease in the first person.
(D)When misused by taking larger-than-prescribed doses, the drug can be fatal.
(E)Use of the drug contributes to the development of deadlier forms of chicken pox that are resistant to the drug.
output: The discrepancy in the statement arises from the fact that while the drug effectively treats chicken pox in patients who use it, its widespread use might still be dangerous. The best candidate would provide a solution that offers both effective treatment but also ensures its safety concerning potential misuse or inappropriate application. In this case, option (D) arguably resolves this paradox most fairly. It implies that the drug, while mostly safe and effective, can turn fatal when used inappropriately (by taking larger-than-prescribed doses). Considering its safety, the risk can be mitigated through education and revised protocols, which would reduce the chances of misuse without limiting its potential benefits in treating chicken pox.

Therefore, if their goal is to make medicine more cost-effective, medical schools spend insufficient time teaching preventive medicine.
Which one of the following is an assumption on which the editorial's argument depends?
(A)Preventive medicine makes use of technologies that are lower in initial cost than the technologies used within the practice of curative medicine.
(B)Every hour devoted to the teaching of preventive medicine reduces medical costs by 10 percent or more.
(C)Medical schools could increase their total number of teaching hours.
(D)Improvements in doctors' use of the techniques of curative medicine would only increase overall medical costs.
(E)The time required to teach preventive medicine thoroughly is greater than one hour for every ten that are now spent teaching curative medicine.
output:
The assumption on which the editorial's argument depends is:

(C) Medical schools could increase their total number of teaching hours.

The argument posits that medical schools should spend more time teaching preventive medicine since it can significantly reduce medical costs. The argument assumes that increasing the total teaching time would allow more time to be dedicated to preventive medicine. Without the potential for extended teaching hours, the argument does not necessarily hold as the schools are already maximizing their usage of the available time.

input:
Experimental psychology requires the application of statistics to interpret empirical data and assess their significance. A person will not be able to understand such applications without training in statistics. Therefore, the more training one has in statistics, the better one will be at research in experimental psychology.
Which one of the following arguments exhibits a flawed pattern of reasoning most similar to that exhibited by the argument above?
(A)Most people need the love and support of others; without it, they become depressed and unhappy. Therefore, in most instances, the more love and support a person receives, the happier that person will be.
(B)Since in most jobs there are annual wage or salary increases, the longer one has worked, the more raises one will have received. Therefore, in a typical job, the longer one has worked, the greater one's income will be.
(C)The main cause of heart attacks is arteriosclerosis, the buildup of plaque on the interior wall of the coronary arteries. It develops over an extended period of time. Therefore, if one is at risk for arteriosclerosis, one becomes more likely to suffer a heart attack as one gets older.
(D)Since many disease processes are biochemical in nature, unless one understands chemistry one will not be able to understand the explanations for many diseases. Therefore, if one has no training in chemistry, one will not be able to master medicine.
(E)Since most disease processes are biochemical in nature, an understanding of chemistry will enable one to understand most diseases. Therefore, one needs little more than training in chemistry to be able to master medicine.
output:
(C) The main cause of heart attacks is arteriosclerosis, the buildup of plaque on the interior wall of the coronary arteries. It develops over an extended period of time. Therefore, if one is at risk for arteriosclerosis, one becomes more likely to suffer a heart attack as one gets older.

This argument exhibits a similar flawed pattern of reasoning to the original argument by oversimplifying the relationship between statistical training and research proficiency in experimental psychology. In the original argument, the conclusion assumes that more statistical training leads to a better understanding of statistical applications in the research without considering other factors. Similarly, the argument about heart attacks and arteriosclerosis assumes a direct correlation between being at risk for arteriosclerosis and the likelihood of suffering a heart attack as one ages, disregarding other possible factors that might contribute to the development of heart attacks.

In 1988 the government of Country X began using a new computer program to determine the number of people employed in that country. The program simply tallied the number of paychecks per pay period issued by employers in X, and used that figure as its estimate of employment. The government reported that, compared with the immediately preceding quarter, there was a large increase in the number of people employed for the first quarter for which the program was used.
Which one of the following can be properly concluded from the information above, together with the fact that in the first quarter for which the program was used, some employers in X issued separate paychecks for the regular hours an employee worked, for the employee's overtime, and for bonuses and commissions?
(A)The government's estimate of growth in the number of people employed was less accurate after the government began using the new program than it had been before.
(B)The people who designed the new program were unaware of the fact that some workers in X receive more than one paycheck per pay period.
(C)The government had not reported strong growth in the number of people employed for the quarters just before the new program was used.
(D)The government overestimated the total number of people employed in X for the first quarter for which the program was used.
(E)Contrary to the claims of the government of Country X, there was no growth in the number of people employed in X in the first quarter for which the program was used.
output:
To solve this task, let's analyze the information provided and examine whether any of the given options can be logically concluded based on the details provided.

Option A: The government's estimate of growth in the number of people employed was less accurate after the program was implemented.

Reasoning: The new program tally's paychecks, not individual employee counts. Some employees received multiple paychecks that could have been categorized as 'employed.' This makes the program less accurate in determining employment as it might count them multiple times. Thus, option A can be concluded.

Option B: The designers of the new program were unaware of workers receiving multiple paychecks.

Reasoning: We cannot infer the designers' knowledge or lack thereof about the unique circumstances of some employees without further information. This conclusion can't be derived from the given details.

Option C: The government had not reported strong growth in the number of people employed before the new system.

Reasoning: The information provided does not specify the government's employment growth reporting before implementing the program. No logical steps can support this conclusion based solely on the given details.

Option D: The government overestimated the total number of people employed in Country X.

Reasoning: Some employees received multiple paychecks. The new program's method could counterintuitively result in an overestimation of employment quantity since it treats each separate paycheck paid out as a separate employment unit. Thus, option D can be concluded.

Option E: There was no growth in the number of people employed in Country X in the first quarter after implementing the new program.

Reasoning: The program reported a large growth in employment but did not consider the unique circumstances of some workers. Thus, the assertion cannot be drawn from the given description.

In conclusion, options A and D can be properly concluded from the information provided and the nature of the issue at hand.

Some vegetarians have argued that there are two individually sufficient reasons for not eating meat— one based on health considerations, and the other based on the aversion to living at the expense of other conscious creatures. But suppose that eating meat were essential to good health for humans. Then it would be less clear that an aversion to living at the expense of other conscious creatures is enough of a reason to stop eating meat.
Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the argument by the supposition that eating meat is essential to good health?
(A)It is used to disprove the vegetarian position that we should not eat meat.
(B)It is used to show that the two types of reasons cited in favor of vegetarianism are independent.
(C)It is used to disprove the claim that a vegetarian diet is healthy.
(D)It is used to weaken the claim that the consciousness of animals is a sufficient reason for not eating meat.
(E)It is used to show that there is no sufficient reason for not eating meat.
output:
The most accurate description of the role played in the argument by the supposition that eating meat is essential to good health is:

(D) It is used to weaken the claim that the consciousness of animals is a sufficient reason for not eating meat.

The argument discusses two reasons for not eating meat, relying on health and ethical considerations against causing harm to other conscious creatures. By introducing the supposition that eating meat is essential to good health, it puts the second reason, an ethical justification, into question by showing that there might be another significant reason for consuming meat - sustaining good health. Thus, the argument seeks to lessen the strength of the ethical argument that stands against consuming meat due to the potential suffering or harm it causes to animals.

The increasing complexity of scientific inquiry has led to a proliferation of multiauthored technical articles. Reports of clinical trials involving patients from several hospitals are usually coauthored by physicians from each participating hospital. Likewise, physics papers reporting results from experiments using subsystems developed at various laboratories generally have authors from each laboratory.
If all the statements above are true, which one of the following must be true?
(A)Clinical trials involving patients from several hospitals are never conducted solely by physicians from just one hospital.
(B)Most reports of clinical trials involving patients from several hospitals have multiple authors.
(C)When a technical article has multiple authors, they are usually from several different institutions.
(D)Physics papers authored by researchers from multiple laboratories usually report results from experiments using subsystems developed at each laboratory.
(E)Most technical articles are authored solely by the researchers who conducted the experiments these articles report.
output:
Based on the given statements, the correct answer is (D) - "Physics papers authored by researchers from multiple laboratories usually report results from experiments using subsystems developed at each laboratory."

Here's a step-by-step breakdown as to why this is the correct choice:

1. The given information states that technical articles, which can be both physics papers and clinical trial reports, often have multiple authors from different institutions (a university lab, for instance).
2. From this, it can be concluded that when a technical article is co-authored, the researchers likely contributed to the work. 
3. Physics papers reporting on collaborative experiments often have authors from each collaborating lab, as mentioned in the statements.
4. So, Physics papers with multiple authors usually correspond to experiments using subsystems developed at each laboratory.

The remaining options are not necessarily true based on the provided information. While the statements imply that it's common for a physics paper to have multiple authors from different labs (Option C), it doesn't mean that it always has to have contributed expertise from each laboratory involved. The sole purpose of contributing authors could be to provide different perspectives in reporting the research (option A). And it's safe to discard the options A and E as they make absolute declarations which aren't backed by the given statements. Lastly, option B is not a must statement either since the given statement talks about reports of clinical trials involving patients from several hospitals having multiple authors, not that they do so most of the time.

output:

Jay disputes Helena's assertion by highlighting that there is variability in the outcomes of the children adopted by extroverts, implying that not all these adopted children become more sociable. He emphasizes that some remain introverted, meaning they do not achieve the sociability level seen in children of introverted parents who are not adopted. Thus, his interpretation focuses on the divergence (not consistency) amongst adopted children as compared to children whose biological parents are introverted. This statement agrees with (C), which states that these children do not tend to be more sociable, challenging Helena's initial conclusion.

(E)It is a conclusion supported by the claim that people's responses under experimental conditions are essentially different from their responses in ordinary situations.

The claim that people have positive or negative responses to many nonsense words plays which one of the following roles in the argument?

(D) It is a premise offered in support of the conclusion that people's responses to words are engendered not only by what the words mean, but also by how they sound.

This claim serves as a premise because it provides evidence to support the broad conclusion that people's responses to words are influenced by more than just their meaning. It shows that auditory aspects (how a word sounds) also play a significant role in shaping people's reactions, which helps build the argument's claim that word responses are conditioned by both their meaning and sound.

People with high blood pressure are generally more nervous and anxious than are people who do not have high blood pressure. This fact shows that this particular combination of personality traits—the so-called hypertensive personality—is likely to cause a person with these traits to develop high blood pressure.
The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the ground that the argument
(A)fails to define the term "hypertensive personality"
(B)presupposes that people have permanent personality traits
(C)simply restates the claim that there is a "hypertensive personality" without providing evidence to support that claim
(D)takes a correlation between personality traits and high blood pressure as proof that the traits cause high blood pressure
(E)focuses on nervousness and anxiety only, ignoring other personality traits that people with high blood pressure might have
output:
The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the ground that the argument:

(D) takes a correlation between personality traits and high blood pressure as proof that the traits cause high blood pressure.

Explanation:

This statement is the most vulnerable to criticism because it incorrectly assumes causation from a correlation. While people with high blood pressure might exhibit certain personality traits, it doesn't mean that these traits are the cause of high blood pressure. It should be carefully examined whether there's actually a causal relationship, or if these traits just coincide with high blood pressure due to another underlying factor.

(B)The passage in Grey's book that employs the unusual metaphor expresses an idea that bears little relation to any ideas expressed in Jordan's book.
(C)Both Grey's book and Jordan's book were written for the same audience.
(D)Jordan used the same metaphor in a work that she wrote in 1894 and published in 1895.
(E)According to most scholars, Grey was generally a more inventive writer than Jordan and developed many original metaphors.
output:
(A) A text that was probably known to both Jordan and Grey was published in 1860 and also contained the same unusual metaphor.

This new information weakens the argument that Grey read Jordan's book because it suggests that the same unusual metaphor was present in a different text that both Jordan and Grey might have known before writing their own respective books. This alternative source for the metaphor reduces the likelihood that Grey copied the metaphor from Jordan's book, instead pointing out the possibility of the metaphor coming from the earlier 1860 publication. In effect, it helps introduce the possibility that providence rather than plagiarism could have been the underlying cause of both writers employing the same metaphor. The other options (B, C, D, and E) do not present such a weakening factor: B actually strengthens the case for plagiarism, C does not affect the argument, D deals with another work by Jordan and not Grey's, and E argues for Grey's inventiveness which does not directly weaken the plagiarism argument.

(A)Medical specialists treat all patients who have serious back muscle injuries with either physical therapy alone or a combination of drugs and physical therapy.
(B)Medical specialists who prescribe these treatments make accurate judgments about who needs both drugs and physical therapy and who needs physical therapy alone.
(C)Some back muscle injuries have been completely healed by a combination of drugs and physical therapy.
(D)Some back muscle injuries that have been aggravated by improper attempts at physical therapy, such as home massage, have been successfully treated with drugs.
(E)Patients with injuries to other muscles show more improvement when treated with both drugs and physical therapy than when treated with physical therapy alone.
output:
To reconcile the medical specialists' two claims, we should look for an option that explains why drugs are necessary for treatment but do not necessarily guarantee better recovery outcomes when combined with physical therapy.

Option (B) fits this criterion: Medical specialists who prescribe these treatments make accurate judgments about who needs both drugs and physical therapy and who needs physical therapy alone.

This answer reconciles the specialists' statements because it suggests that drugs may still be an essential part of the treatment (making them necessary) but can only further improve recovery outcomes when combined with physical therapy when the medical specialist deems it necessary. This explains why patients with back muscle injuries who received drugs and physical therapy didn't fare better than those with only physical therapy - the drugs’ benefit is dependent on individual circumstances and medical judgments.

Commentator: In many countries the influence of fringe movements is increasing. The great centrifugal engine of modern culture turns faster and faster, spinning off fashions, ideologies, religions, artistic movements, economic theories, cults, and dogmas in fabulous profusion. Hence, modern culture threatens the national identities that now exist in the world.
Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the commentator's argument?
(A)New national identities are often forged out of conflicts among diverse groups.
(B)A stable national identity is typically a composite of a staggering number of subcultures.
(C)The rate of cultural change in most countries will soon change drastically.
(D)It is preferable to have a pluralistic rather than a monolithic national culture.
(E)A culture with a solidified national identity tends to have more social problems than one without such an identity.
output:
(B) A stable national identity is typically a composite of a staggering number of subcultures.

This statement weakens the commentator's argument because it implies that a robust national identity can exist despite the influences of various fringe movements and diverse subcultures. In other words, it's possible for a nation to maintain its identity amidst cultural diversity, explaining why modern culture may not always pose a direct threat to existing national identities.

Packaging is vital to a product's commercial success. For example, the maker of a popular drink introduced a "new, improved" version which succeeded in blind taste tests. However, customers did not buy the product when marketed, mainly because the can, almost identical to that used for the earlier version of the beverage, made consumers expect that the new product would share certain features of the old, an expectation not satisfied by the new product.
Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
(A)Proper product packaging is more important than the quality of the product.
(B)Products generally succeed in the market if they are packaged in a manner that accurately reflects their nature.
(C)Changing the packaging of a product will not improve the product's sales unless the product is also changed.
(D)To succeed in the market, a new product should not be packaged in a way that creates expectations that it does not meet.
(E)An improved version of an existing product will sell better than the earlier version unless the improved version is packaged like the earlier one.
output:
Step 1: Analyze the information provided.
- The producer introduced a new drink version that did well in blind taste tests.
- Consumers did not buy the new drink after seeing the similar packaging to the old drink.

Step 2: Identify the main issue.
- Expectations created by old packaging conflicted with the new drink's qualities.

Step 3: Evaluate the given options in relation to the identified issue.

Option (A): Incorrect. The importance of product packaging is not compared to product quality in the information provided.

Option (B): Incorrect. Although packaging reflecting the product's nature is necessary, there is no general guarantee for success mentioned.

Option (C): Incorrect. It does not specify that packaging change is a guarantee for sales improvement unless the product is changed.

Option (D): Correct. To succeed in the market, it is important not to create expectations that the product does not fulfill.

Option (E): Incorrect. The new product selling better than the old version relies on proper packaging that doesn't imply expectations not met instead of being packaged like the older one.

Based on the analysis, the answer supported by the information above is:

(D) To succeed in the market, a new product should not be packaged in a way that creates expectations that it does not meet.

They dispute the accuracy of measuring relative economic prosperity based purely on percentage changes, even though the percentage change presents a clearer comparison between the two groups.

input:
Challenge can be an important source of self-knowledge, since those who pay attention to how they react, both emotionally and physically, to challenge can gain useful insights into their own weaknesses.
Which one of the following most closely conforms to the principle above?
(A)A concert pianist should not have an entirely negative view of a memory lapse during a difficult performance. By understanding why the memory lapse occurred, the pianist can better prepare for future performances.
(B)A salesperson should understand that the commission earned is not the only reward of making a sale. Salespeople should also take satisfaction from the fact that successful sales reflect well on their personalities.
(C)Compassion is valuable not only for the wonderful feelings it brings, but also for the opportunities it affords to enrich the lives of other people.
(D)While some of the value of competition comes from the pleasure of winning, the primary reward of competition is competition itself.
(E)Even people who dread public speaking should accept invitations to speak before large groups. People will admire their courage and they will experience the fulfillment of having attempted something that is difficult for them.
output:
Step 1: Read the given challenge and principle carefully.

Challenge:
Self-knowledge can be obtained by paying attention to how the response to a challenge, both emotional and physical, reveals personal weaknesses.

Principle:
Those who identify their weaknesses and prepare for improvement in response to challenges, are able to grow personally and professionally.

Step 2: Analyze the options based on the above challenge and principle.

Option A: The focus in this option is on identifying and learning from a memory lapse during a piano performance, which helps the pianist to improve for future performances. This option aligns with the principle above, as it involves personal growth through dealing with a challenge and learning from the experience.

Option B: This option talks about understanding the broader rewards of sales beyond monetary gain. Although it expresses personal satisfaction in a challenge, it does not specifically mention improvement or growth from challenges. Thus, it does not align directly with the principle.

Option C: This option highlights the value of compassion, both in personal growth and in enriching the lives of others. However, it does not directly connect with identifying and addressing personal weaknesses through challenges. It is not in alignment with the given principle.

Option D: This option focuses on the value of competition, but does not discuss overcoming personal weaknesses or learning from challenges. Therefore, it is not in alignment with the principle.

Option E: This option encourages facing challenges (public speaking) to learn from the experience. It also highlights the importance of recognizing personal weaknesses. This idea aligns with the principle, although it does not explicitly focus on improving for future situations and growth, similar to Option A.

Step 3: Choose the opinion that most closely conforms to the challenge and principle.

Based on the analysis, the option that most closely conforms to the given challenge and principle is:

(A) A concert pianist should not have an entirely negative view of a memory lapse during a difficult performance. By understanding why the memory lapse occurred, the pianist can better prepare for future performances.

In some countries, national planners have attempted to address the problems resulting from increasing urbanization by reducing migration from rural areas. But some economists have suggested an alternative approach. These economists assert that planners could solve these problems effectively by trading goods or services produced by a predominantly urban population in order to obtain the agricultural products that were previously produced domestically.
Which one of the following, if true, would provide the most support for the economists' assertion?
(A)Government subsidies to urban manufacturers can ease the problems caused by the migration of people from rural to urban areas.
(B)All problems that have economic causes must have economic solutions.
(C)A scarcity of agricultural products is a central element of many problems created by urbanization.
(D)Problems associated with migration to cities from rural areas are primarily due to trade imbalances between countries.
(E)Free trade policies can exacerbate the problems caused by increasing urbanization.
output:
To evaluate the options and choose the one that provides the most support for the economists' assertion, we need to find the statement that aligns with the idea of trading goods or services produced by a predominantly urban population to obtain agricultural products that were previously produced domestically.

(A) The statement suggests that government subsidies for urban manufacturers might alleviate issues arising from rural-urban migration. Although this statement shows some support for the economists' approach, it does not address the specific idea of trading goods and services.

(B) The statement asserts that economic solutions should solve economic causes. While it is a broad affirmation, it does not specify how trading between urban and rural areas could effectively solve the problems.

(C) This statement highlights that agricultural product scarcity is a significant issue generated by urbanization. The trade of goods and services produced by the urban population in exchange for agricultural products would directly address this scarcity. Hence, it provides the strongest support for the economists' assertion as it highlights the relevance of trade in solving the problem identified.

(D) The statement focuses on trade imbalances between countries rather than within a country like in the economists' assertion. Therefore, it doesn't directly support the economists' position.

(E) This option contradicts the economists' belief by stating that free trade can worsen problems related to increasing urbanization.

Based on this analysis, option (C) provides the most support for the economists' assertion. A scarcity of agricultural products is a central element of many problems created by urbanization, making it crucial to employ trade as a solution. Trading goods and services from urban areas for agricultural products reduces the pressure on domestic production and efficiently manages urbanization-related challenges.

input:
In 1963, a young macaque monkey was observed venturing into a hot spring to retrieve food which had fallen in. Soon, other macaques began to enter the spring, and over a few years this behavior was adopted by the entire troop. Prior to 1963, no macaques had ever been observed in the hot spring; by 1990, the troop was regularly spending time there during the winters. Thus, these macaques are able to adopt and pass on new patterns of social behavior, and are not complete captives of their genetic heritage.
Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument above?
(A)Mutations in the genetic heritage of a certain variety of macaques can occur over a time span as short as a few years or decades.
(B)New patterns of behavior that emerge in macaque populations over the course of a few years or decades are not necessarily genetically predetermined.
(C)Only when behaviors become typical among an animal population can we conclude that a genetic alteration has occurred in that variety or species.
(D)The social behaviors of macaques are completely independent of their genetic heritage.
(E)The macaques' new pattern of behavior will persist over several generations.
output:
The correct assumption required by the argument above is (B) New patterns of behavior that emerge in macaque populations over the course of a few years or decades are not necessarily genetically predetermined.

This assumption is needed because the argument discusses how the macaques adopted the new behavior of entering hot springs to retrieve food, which was not observed prior to 1963. This shows that the behavior was acquired, suggesting that it was not fixed within a shorter time period, like a few years or decades. Instead, the behavior was learned and passed on among the troop, and does not require biological evolution at that time scale. Other options involve assumptions about genetic mutation, future behavior persistence, or completely separating social behavior from genetic heritage, which are not explicitly needed for the argument.

(A)contains a premise that cannot possibly be true
(B)takes for granted that technology beneficial to society as a whole cannot be commercially viable
(C)fails to consider the possibility that actions motivated by a desire for personal gain often do not result in personal gain
(D)takes for granted that an action is unlikely to produce a certain outcome unless it is motivated by a desire to produce that outcome
(E)draws a conclusion about the practical consequences of people's actions on the basis of theoretical views about what people should or should not do
output:
The argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it (B) takes for granted that technology beneficial to society as a whole cannot be commercially viable.

This criticism addresses the assumption that there is an inherent conflict between technological advances aimed at serving societal interests and those intended for commercial success. In reality, several technological breakthroughs have demonstrated both the potential for societal benefit and commercial viability. Complex systems such as the internet, smartphones, and various medical technologies have made significant contributions to society while simultaneously generating substantial profits for their creators. Furthermore, considerations of social responsibility and ethical conduct can lead to the development and commercialization of technology that benefits society as a whole, and receive additional long-term benefits in terms of public trust, corporate reputation, and market opportunities.

input:
There are two kinds of horror stories: those that describe a mad scientist's experiments and those that describe a monstrous beast. In some horror stories about monstrous beasts, the monster symbolizes a psychological disturbance in the protagonist. Horror stories about mad scientists, on the other hand, typically express the author's feeling that scientific knowledge alone is not enough to guide human endeavor. However, despite these differences, both kinds of horror stories share two features: they describe violations of the laws of nature and they are intended to produce dread in the reader.
If the statements above are true, which one of the following would also have to be true?
(A)All descriptions of monstrous beasts describe violations of the laws of nature.
(B)Any story that describes a violation of a law of nature is intended to invoke dread in the reader.
(C)Horror stories of any kind usually describe characters who are psychologically disturbed.
(D)Most stories about mad scientists express the author's antiscientific views.
(E)Some stories that employ symbolism describe violations of the laws of nature.
output:
Let's examine each statement option based on the given information:

(A) All descriptions of monstrous beasts describe violations of the laws of nature.
According to the given information, monstrous beasts sometimes symbolize psychological disturbances in the protagonist. While this does not explicitly exclude the possibility of describing violations of the laws of nature, it does not necessarily mean that all such stories would adhere to that. Thus, we cannot conclude A must be true.

(B) Any story that describes a violation of a law of nature is intended to invoke dread in the reader.
The given information states that both kinds of horror stories (those with monstrous beasts and those with mad scientists) share the feature of violating the laws of nature and invoking dread. However, this statement is too broad, as it implies that this combination will be present in every story mentioning violation of laws of nature, which might not be true.

(C) Horror stories of any kind usually describe characters who are psychologically disturbed.
According to the information given, only some horror stories about monstrous beasts symbolize a psychological disturbance in the protagonist. This doesn't necessarily mean that horror stories of any kind usually have psychological disturbed characters, making C not necessarily true.

(D) Most stories about mad scientists express the author's antiscientific views.
The given information states that "story about mad scientists, on the other hand, typically expresses the author's feeling that scientific knowledge alone is not enough to guide human endeavor." It doesn't say that most of these stories are antiscientific, just that this is a common theme. Therefore, not all stories about mad scientists express antiscientific views, making D incorrect.

(E) Some stories that employ symbolism describe violations of the laws of nature.
Since some horror stories about monstrous beasts use the monster to symbolize a psychological disturbance, it's clear that there exists at least one instance where symbolism is used in conjunction with violations of the laws of nature. This makes E the correct answer as it must be true based on given information.

Politician: Some of my opponents have argued on theoretical grounds in favor of reducing social spending. Instead of arguing that there is excessive public expenditure on social programs, my opponents should focus on the main cause of deficit spending: the fact that government is bloated with bureaucrats and self-aggrandizing politicians. It is unwarranted, therefore, to reduce social expenditure.
A reasoning flaw in the politician's argument is that the argument
(A)does not address the arguments advanced by the politician's opponents
(B)makes an attack on the character of opponents
(C)takes for granted that deficit spending has just one cause
(D)portrays opponents' views as more extreme than they really are
(E)fails to make clear what counts as excessive spending
output:
The reasoning flaw in the politician's argument is (C) takes for granted that deficit spending has just one cause.

The politician ignores various other potential causes of deficit spending, such as economic downturns, higher interest rates, or tax cuts that don't result in expected economic growth. Simply stating that the government is bloated with bureaucrats and self-aggrandizing politicians oversimplifies this complex issue. The argument is flawed because it assumes that reducing the number of bureaucrats and politicians will solve the problem of deficit spending without considering other underlying factors.

input:
While it is true that bees' vision is well suited to the task of identifying flowers by their colors, it is probable that flowers developed in response to the type of vision that bees have, rather than bees' vision developing in response to flower color.
Which one of the following, if true, most strongly supports the statement above?
(A)Many insects that have vision very similar to that of bees do not depend on perceiving an object's color.
(B)Some flowers rely on insects other than bees.
(C)The number of different species of flowers is greater than the number of different species of bees.
(D)Many nonflowering plants rely on bees.
(E)Present-day bees rely exclusively on flowers for their food.
output:
To strengthen the statement that flowers developed in response to the type of vision bees have, and not bees' vision adapting to flower color, we need evidence that shows a vision mechanism in flowers that attracts bees to them. This mechanism must be independent of color perception.

Option A states that many insects with similar vision to bees don't depend on perceiving color for their object recognition. This suggests that other bees-like insects have eyes that are attuned to flower features other than color, which might indicate that lavishing attention on color is not necessarily the best strategy for attracting such creatures. This fact might strengthen our case since it could mean that flowers evolved to take advantage of such other mechanisms, not specifically color vision.

Thus, option A best supports the statement that flowers likely evolved in response to the type of vision bees have, rather than bees' vision adapting to flower color. The other options don't directly indicate that the color vision of bees or other insects has influenced flowers' adaptation strategies.

input:
Professor: It has been argued that freedom of thought is a precondition for intellectual progress, because freedom of thought allows thinkers to pursue their ideas, regardless of whom these ideas offend, in whatever direction they lead. However, it is clear that one must mine the full implications of interrelated ideas to make intellectual progress, and for this, thinkers need intellectual discipline. Therefore, this argument for freedom of thought fails.
The conclusion drawn by the professor follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
(A)Thinkers who limit their line of thought to a particular orthodoxy are hindered in their intellectual progress.
(B)Thinkers can mine the full implications of interrelated ideas only in the context of a society that values intellectual progress.
(C)In societies that protect freedom of thought, thinkers invariably lack intellectual discipline.
(D)Freedom of thought engenders creativity, which aids the discovery of truth.
(E)Without intellectual discipline, thinkers can have no freedom of thought.
output:
The conclusion drawn by the professor states that the argument for freedom of thought fails due to the need for intellectual discipline while mining the full implications of interrelated ideas. Therefore, the assumption required for this conclusion to follow logically is that:

(E) Without intellectual discipline, thinkers can have no freedom of thought.

This assumption is needed because it directly ties freedom of thought to the requirement of intellectual discipline. If one assumes that without intellectual discipline, thinkers cannot act freely, the argument that freedom of thought alone is insufficient would logically follow. The other choices (A, B, C, and D) do not directly address this relationship.

input:
People who have specialized knowledge about a scientific or technical issue are systematically excluded from juries for trials where that issue is relevant. Thus, trial by jury is not a fair means of settling disputes involving such issues.
Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
(A)The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
(B)The more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
(C)Appointing an impartial arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues, because arbitrators tend to favor settlements in which both parties compromise on the issues.
(D)Experts who give testimony on scientific or technical issues tend to hedge their conclusions by discussing the possibility of error.
(E)Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
output:
Step 1: Identify the argument
The argument states that the exclusion of people with specialized knowledge from juries for trials involving scientific or technical issues makes trial by jury unfair.

Step 2: Analyze the provided options
Each option is examined to determine whether it weakens or strengthens the argument.

(A) This option supports the argument that the complexity of the issue makes the trial unfair, as it explains that lack of specialized knowledge compromises the juror's ability to comprehend testimony.

(B) This option weakens the argument by proposing that jurors with knowledge might be biased toward one party, furthering the claim that trials may not be fair.

(C) This option is unrelated to the topic of specialists being excluded from juries but discusses the fairness of arbitration, making it irrelevant for addressing the argument.

(D) This option suggests that expert witnesses may not be completely trustworthy due to their hesitation to give definitive judgments. However, this weakness does not directly target the argument about excluding specialists from juries.

(E) This option addresses the high fees that specialized experts may charge, potentially limiting litigants' ability to use their expertise in trials. However, this issue concerns financial accessibility rather than the fairness of trials with jury exclusion of specialists.

Step 3: Determine which option best weakens the argument
Out of all the options, (B) best weakens the argument about the uncertainty and unfairness of trials involving specialized knowledge, as it introduces the potential bias among jurors who may have knowledge in their field. This possibility points to another reason why excluding specialists from juries for such cases may not sufficiently promote fairness.

input:
If one has evidence that an act will benefit other people and performs that act to benefit them, then one will generally succeed in benefiting them.
Which one of the following best illustrates the proposition above?
(A)A country's leaders realized that fostering diplomatic ties with antagonistic nations reduces the chances of war with those nations. Because those leaders worried that war would harm their chances of being reelected, they engaged in diplomatic discussions with a hostile country, and the two countries avoided a confrontation.
(B)A government study concluded that a proposed bureaucratic procedure would allow people to register their cars without waiting in line. The government adopted the procedure for this reason, and, as with most bureaucratic procedures, it was not successful.
(C)Betsy overheard a heating contractor say that regularly changing the filter in a furnace helps to keep the furnace efficient. So Betsy has regularly changed the furnace filter in her daughter's house. As a result, the furnace has never required maintenance due to becoming clogged with dust or dirt.
(D)Sejal learned in a psychology class that the best way to help someone overcome an addiction is to confront that person. So she confronted her friend Bob, who was struggling with a chemical dependency.
(E)Zachary hoped that psychotherapy could help his parents overcome their marital difficulties. He persuaded his parents to call a psychotherapist, and eventually their problems were resolved.
output: The best illustration of the proposition 'If one has evidence that an act will benefit other people and performs that act to benefit them, then one will generally succeed in benefiting them' is (A). The country's leaders decided to engage in diplomatic discussions after realizing that it would benefit both nations by reducing the chances of war, thus avoiding a confrontation. This example clearly demonstrates how the leaders used their evidence to perform an act beneficial to both countries, leading to a successful outcome.

Radio airplay restrictions are nationally imposed regulations. The City Club has compiled a guide to all nationally imposed regulations except those related to taxation or to labor law. Radio airplay restrictions are related neither to taxation nor to labor law, so the City Club's guide covers radio airplay restrictions.
Which one of the following exhibits a pattern of reasoning most similar to that exhibited by the argument above?
(A)All prepackaged desserts pose a risk of tooth decay. The Nutrition Foundation recommends avoiding all prepackaged desserts that are not high in vitamins or protein. Many prepackaged snack foods are low in vitamins or protein, so the Nutrition Foundation recommends avoiding prepackaged snack foods as well.
(B)Coreopsis is a perennial. The Garden Club awards a prize each year for each perennial except those that are shrubs or not native to North America. Coreopsis is native to North America and is not a shrub. So the Garden Club awards a prize each year for coreopsis.
(C)The Windsor Coalition is an example of a community organizing to discourage overdevelopment. The Neighborhood Association is in favor of this sort of community organizing, except when it poses a threat to regional economic growth. Therefore, the Neighborhood Association is in favor of the Windsor Coalition.
(D)Compact discs are a kind of data storage device. Leotol Corporation does not produce data storage devices that use analog storage methods. Compact discs do not use analog storage methods, so it follows that Leotol Corporation produces compact discs.
(E)Traffic laws are a type of government regulation. The association supports traffic laws that are in the public interest, even if they have not been shown to reduce the accident rate. Thus, the association should support all government regulations that are in the public interest.
output: (A)This exhibits a pattern of reasoning that is similar to the given argument. The garden club's guide to regulations covers a specific category (perennials that are neither shrubs nor non-native to North America), and the conclusion is drawn based on the mentioned characteristics (Coreopsis is native to North America and is not a shrub). Both arguments operate on specific listed categories and draw conclusions based on renowned characteristics related to that category.

input:
Physics professor: Some scientists claim that superheated plasma in which electrical resistance fails is a factor in causing so-called "ball lightning." If this were so, then such lightning would emit intense light and, since plasma has gaslike properties, would rise in the air. However, the instances of ball lightning that I observed were of low intensity and floated horizontally before vanishing. Thus, superheated plasma with failed electrical resistance is never a factor in causing ball lightning.
The physics professor's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
(A)Superheated plasma in which electrical resistance fails does not cause types of lightning other than ball lightning.
(B)The phenomena observed by the physics professor were each observed by at least one other person.
(C)Ball lightning can occur as the result of several different factors.
(D)Superheating of gaslike substances causes bright light to be emitted.
(E)All types of ball lightning have the same cause.
output:
The professor's conclusion that superheated plasma with failed electrical resistance is never a factor in causing ball lightning follows logically if option (C) "Ball lightning can occur as the result of several different factors." is assumed.

From the provided statement, we know that the professor thinks superheated plasma with failed electrical resistance (which emits intense light and rises in the air) should cause ball lightning. But the examples he observed were of low intensity and floated horizontally before disappearing. This indicates that his observations don't match with those that occur due to superheated plasma with failed electrical resistance.

If we assume that there are several factors that can lead to the creation of ball lightning (Option C), then the failures in superheated plasma aren't always the cause of ball lightning. This provides a logical explanation for the professor's observations not aligning with the expected characteristics.

input:
Advertisement: Our oat bran cereal is the only one that has printed right on its package all of its claimed health benefits. And really health-conscious consumers have demonstrated that these health claims are true by buying our cereal since they would not have bought our cereal unless the claims were true. How do we know these consumers are really health-conscious? No really health-conscious consumer would buy food in a package that did not have accurate information about the food's health benefits printed on it.
Which one of the following employs a flawed argumentative strategy that is most closely parallel to the flawed argumentative strategy in the advertisement above?
(A)Greeting one's coworkers must be a polite thing to do, because people who are considered polite always greet their coworkers. The proof that these people really are polite is that they are consistently polite in their daily lives.
(B)This card game must be intellectually challenging, because it is played by highly intelligent people, who play only intellectually challenging card games. In fact, these players' intelligence is demonstrated by the fact that they play this game.
(C)When coffee is being chosen, Brand Z is the coffee chosen by people with highly developed taste in coffee. These people showed their highly developed taste in coffee by correctly distinguishing eight brands of coffee from each other in a taste test.
(D)That jacket must have been made for a very short person, because only very short people were able to fit into it. We know that they were very short because we saw them before they tried on the jacket.
(E)This painting is a poor imitation, because only people with poor eyesight mistook it for the original. That these people have poor eyesight is demonstrated by the fact that they also mistook a vase of flowers in the painting for a peacock.
output:
The flawed argumentative strategy used in the advertisement is circular reasoning. This happens when the conclusion of an argument is also used as one of its premises. 

There's a flaw in the argument because it assumes the health-conscious consumers are buying the oat bran cereal simply because they're health-conscious and it's proven their claims by their behavior (buying the cereal). There is no independent evidence presented as to why the product has the health benefits claimed. Instead, the belief in the claim is used as proof for the existence of the claim, thus it's circular reasoning.

Among the answers given, option (E) also uses a circular reasoning: "only people with poor eyesight mistook it for the original. That these people have poor eyesight is demonstrated by the fact that they also mistook a vase of flowers for a peacock." The conclusion that the painting is a poor imitation is also used as a premise to argue the eyesight of the onlookers, creating a circular reasoning. Therefore, option (E) employs the same flawed argumentative strategy as the original advertisement.

input:
A study of 86 patients, all of whom suffered from disease T and received the same standard medical treatment, divided the patients into 2 equal groups. One group's members all attended weekly support group meetings, but no one from the other group attended support group meetings. After 10 years, 41 patients from each group had died. Clearly, support group meetings do not help patients with disease T live longer.
Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
(A)Of the 4 patients who survived more than 10 years, the 2 who had attended weekly support group meetings lived longer than the 2 who had not.
(B)For many diseases, attending weekly support group meetings is part of the standard medical treatment.
(C)The members of the group that attended weekly support group meetings lived 2 years longer, on average, than the members of the other group.
(D)Some physicians have argued that attending weekly support group meetings gives patients less faith in the standard treatment for disease T.
(E)Everyone in the group whose members attended weekly support group meetings reported after 1 year that those meetings had helped them to cope with the disease.
output:
(D)Some physicians have argued that attending weekly support group meetings gives patients less faith in the standard treatment for disease T.

This statement weakens the original argument because it introduces the possibility that the support group meetings could impact the efficacy of the standard medical treatment for disease T. If patients lose faith in the standard treatment due to attending support group meetings, the outcomes of the study may not accurately reflect the potential benefits of support group attendance. The study's results could be influenced by this change in perspective, making the conclusion about the lack of impact of support group meetings on patient survival less certain.

input:
Astronomer: I have asserted that our solar system does not contain enough meteoroids and other cosmic debris to have caused the extensive cratering on the far side of the moon. My opponents have repeatedly failed to demonstrate the falsity of this thesis. Their evidence is simply inconclusive; thus they should admit that my thesis is correct.
The reasoning in the astronomer's argument is flawed because this argument
(A)criticizes the astronomer's opponents rather than their arguments
(B)infers the truth of the astronomer's thesis from the mere claim that it has not been proven false
(C)ignores the possibility that alternative explanations may exist for the cratering
(D)presumes that the astronomer's thesis should not be subject to rational discussion and criticism
(E)fails to precisely define the key word "meteoroids"
output: The reasoning in the astronomer's argument is flawed because it (D) presumes that the astronomer's thesis should not be subject to rational discussion and criticism. In a scientific debate or discourse, every thesis or claim brought forward should be open to discussion, criticism, and evaluation of evidence. Dismissing the opponent's arguments for simply being inconclusive does not demonstrate the validity or correctness of the original thesis. Instead, it would be more appropriate to engage in constructive discourse and analyze the evidence presented by both sides.

input:
Many newborn babies have a yellowish tinge to their skin because their blood contains a high level of the pigment bilirubin. One group of doctors treats newborns to reduce high levels of bilirubin, since bilirubin, if it enters the brain, might cause the tetanus that sometimes occurs in newborns. However, a second group of doctors argues for allowing bilirubin levels in newborn babies to remain high, since the brain's own natural defenses normally prevent bilirubin from entering.
Which one of the following, if true, most helps to support the position of the second group of doctors?
(A)The treatment that most effectively reduces high levels of bilirubin in newborns has no known negative side effects.
(B)Some diseases that occur in newborns can weaken the brain's natural defenses and allow bilirubin to enter.
(C)In newborns the pigment bilirubin, like other pigments, occurs not only in the blood but also in fluids involved in digestion.
(D)Bilirubin neutralizes certain potentially damaging substances to which newborns are exposed at birth.
(E)Among doctors who recommend treating newborns to reduce high levels of bilirubin, there is general agreement about what levels should be considered excessively high.
output:
The second group of doctors argues for allowing bilirubin levels in newborn babies to remain high because the brain's own natural defenses normally prevent bilirubin from entering. So, in order to support their position, we need to find a statement that provides evidence that the brain's natural defenses are strong enough to prevent bilirubin from causing damage.

Option B) provides relevant information that helps to support the position of the second group of doctors. It states, "Some diseases that occur in newborns can weaken the brain's natural defenses and allow bilirubin to enter." This statement suggests that the brain's natural defenses, which normally prevent bilirubin from entering the brain, can be compromised due to other diseases. Therefore, it might not always be necessary or beneficial to administer treatments that reduce bilirubin levels just to prevent potential damage to the brain from bilirubin. The presence of other diseases that can weaken these defenses makes it more important to consider the overall health and well-being of the newborn rather than focusing exclusively on bilirubin levels. This strengthens the argument of the second group of doctors that bilirubin levels can remain high in newborns, as long as overall health is monitored.

input:
Economist:Some sociologists argue that because capitalism intrinsically involves competition, it weakens the ties between the people of a community. Although this may formerly have been true, modern capitalism requires that there be large corporations. Thus, modern capitalism promotes, rather than weakens, communal ties.
Which one of the following is an assumption on which the economist's argument depends?
(A)Few economic systems are more successful than modern capitalism in fostering communal ties between citizens.
(B)Modern capitalism is designed primarily to distribute goods and services, not to create communal ties between people.
(C)Corporations that compete with each other must develop some ties to each other in order to reach agreement on the rules of the competition.
(D)Having large corporations in a modern capitalist system promotes the strength of communal ties.
(E)An economic system that does not encourage large corporations will be less successful economically than one that does.
output:
The economist's argument assumes that modern capitalism promotes, rather than weakens, communal ties. To evaluate the given options, let's breakdown the economist's argument:

1. Capitalism involves competition.
2. Capitalism requires large corporations.
3. Modern capitalism promotes communal ties.

The assumption here is that large corporations help foster these communal ties.

Option (D) "Having large corporations in a modern capitalist system promotes the strength of communal ties." directly matches this assumption, making it the correct choice.
task_prompt:

Columnist: Donating items to charity may be a sign of generosity, but any generosity it may demonstrate is rarely a permanent virtue, since most donors make donations only intermittently.
Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the columnist's argument?
(A)The argument takes for granted that truly generous people are the most virtuous.
(B)The argument attacks the character of those whose values are different from those of the columnist.
(C)The argument takes for granted that a character trait is present only when manifested.
(D)The argument generalizes from too small a sample of cases.
(E)The argument takes for granted that most people donate out of generosity.
output: The flaw in the columnist's argument can be best described by option (C): The argument takes for granted that a character trait is present only when manifested. The columnist assumes that intermittent donations cannot indicate a permanent virtue if the individual doesn't donate consistently. However, this overlooks the fact that virtuous characters might express their kindness through various actions at different times, not merely through constant donations.

Violent crime in this town is becoming a serious problem. Compared to last year, local law enforcement agencies have responded to 17 percent more calls involving violent crimes, showing that the average citizen of this town is more likely than ever to become a victim of a violent crime.
Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
(A)The town's overall crime rate appears to have risen slightly this year compared to the same period last year.
(B)In general, persons under the age of 65 are less likely to be victims of violent crimes than persons over the age of 65.
(C)As a result of the town's community outreach programs, more people than ever are willing to report violent crimes to the proper authorities.
(D)In response to worries about violent crime, the town has recently opened a community center providing supervised activities for teenagers.
(E)Community officials have shown that a relatively small number of repeat offenders commit the majority of violent crimes in the town.
output:
C) As a result of the town's community outreach programs, more people than ever are willing to report violent crimes to the proper authorities.

This statement weakens the argument by suggesting that the increase in violent crime reports may be partially due to the town's efforts to encourage people to report crimes rather than an actual increase in violent crime occurrences. If the community is more aware and willing to come forward with information, it could be misconstrued as a rise in violent crimes when in reality, it is just better reporting.

Two different dates have been offered as the approximate end point of the last ice age in North America. The first date was established by testing insect fragments found in samples of sediments to determine when warmth-adapted open-ground beetles replaced cold-adapted arctic beetles. The second date was established by testing pollen grains in those same samples to determine when ice masses yielded to spruce forests. The first date is more than 500 years earlier than the second.
The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following conclusions about the last ice age and its aftermath in North America?
(A)Toward the end of the ice age, warmth-adapted open-ground beetles ceased to inhabit areas where the predominant tree cover consisted of spruce forests.
(B)Among those sediments deposited toward the end of the ice age, those found to contain cold-adapted arctic beetle fragments can also be expected to contain spruce-pollen grains.
(C)Ice masses continued to advance through North America for several hundred years after the end of the ice age.
(D)The species of cold-adapted arctic beetle that inhabited areas covered by ice masses died out toward the end of the last ice age.
(E)Toward the end of the ice age, warmth-adapted open-ground beetles colonized the new terrain opened to them faster than soil changes and seed dispersion established new spruce forests.
output:
The task involves evaluating the relationship between the study of insect fragments found in sediments and pollen grains in determining different dates for the end of the last ice age in North America. The first date corresponds to the replacement of cold-adapted arctic beetles by warmth-adapted open-ground beetles, while the second date signifies the transition of the landscape from ice masses to spruce forests.

Examine each statement:

A. As warmth-adapted open-ground beetles replaced cold-adapted arctic beetles, this indicates a shift from the presence of ice masses to an environment where open-ground beetles thrived and spruce forests were less likely to be present.

B. The statement cannot be concluded based on the provided information, as it does not consider changes over time.

C. The information given does not suggest that ice masses continued to advance for several hundred years. Instead, the first date appears to mark the end of the ice age when open-ground beetles adapted to warmth began to replace their cold-adapted counterparts.

D. This statement seems reasonable as the transition from ice-covered terrain to an environment able to host warmth-adapted open-ground beetles would likely accompany the eventual end of the ice age and the decline of ancient arctic beetle species.

E. This conclusion might be plausible as the advance or faster colonization of open-ground beetles compared to soil changes and seed dispersal could contribute to a faster conversion of ice masses to spruce forests.

Among the given conclusions, option (D) "The species of cold-adapted arctic beetle that inhabited areas covered by ice masses died out toward the end of the last ice age." is the most strongly supported conclusion based on the information provided.

input:
When presented with the evidence against him, Ellison freely admitted to engaging in illegal transactions using company facilities. However, the company obtained the evidence by illegally recording Ellison's conversations. Therefore, although the company may demand that he immediately cease, it cannot justifiably take any punitive measures against him.
Which one of the following judgments best illustrates the principle illustrated by the argument above?
(A)After Price confessed to having stolen money from Long over a period of several years, Long began stealing from Price. Despite Price's guilt, Long was not justified in taking illegal action against him.
(B)Shakila's secretary has admitted that he is illegally receiving cable television without paying for it. Shakila would not be justified in reporting him, though, since she once did the same thing.
(C)After Takashi told Sarah's parents that he had seen her at the movies on Tuesday, Sarah confessed to sneaking out that day. On Monday, however, Takashi had violated the local curfew for minors. Hence Sarah's parents cannot justifiably punish her in this case.
(D)After a conservation officer discovered them, Kuttner admitted that he had set the illegal animal traps on his land. But, because she was trespassing at the time, the conservation officer cannot justifiably punish Kuttner in this case.
(E)Ramirez was forced by the discovery of new evidence to admit that she lied about her role in managing the chief of staff's financial affairs. Nevertheless, the board of directors cannot justifiably take action against Ramirez, because in past instances it has pardoned others guilty of similar improprieties.
output: The best judgment that illustrates the principle shown by the argument is (B). Shakila would not be justified in reporting her secretary for illegal cable television. This choice closely parallels the company in the original argument not being justified in taking punitive measures against Ellison. Both instances reflect an appeal to act - in the original, to take Ellison off as a director; in the analogy, Shakila should not report her secretary. The line of reasoning involves an attraction to equity but fails against the backdrop of unethical approach of gathering the initial evidence—illegal recording in the original and prior justifications for similar actions in option (B).

input:
In a recent study, each member of two groups of people, Group A (composed of persons sixty-five to seventy-five years old) and Group B (composed of college students), was required to make a telephone call to a certain number at a specified time. The time when each call was initiated was recorded electronically. Group A proved far better at remembering to make a telephone call precisely at a specified time than did Group B. There were fourteen lapses in Group B but only one lapse in Group A. Clearly, at least one type of memory does not suffer as a person ages.
Which one of the following, if all of them are true, is LEAST helpful in establishing that the conclusion above is properly drawn?
(A)There was the same number of people in each group.
(B)The same group of researchers answered the calls made by the callers in both study groups.
(C)Among the college students there were no persons more than forty years old.
(D)Both groups had unrestricted access to telephones for making the required calls.
(E)The members of the two groups received their instructions approximately the same amount of time before they were to make their telephone calls.
output:
Let's carefully evaluate each of these options for its effectiveness in supporting the conclusion that a certain type of memory does not decline with age often disregarding option (A) since it's neutral to the conclusion.

(B) The same group of researchers answering the calls made by callers from both groups could introduce several biases such as carelessness or lack of experience handling diverse age groups or various communication styles. These biases could affect group B's performance and wrongly attribute it to memory decline rather than to any specific study design issue.

(C) This option doesn't directly affect the conclusion since it's about the age range for a subgroup in Group B. Whether or not there were older members in Group B (>40 years old) doesn't change the fact Group A (65-75 years old) had fewer lapses over the same task.

(D) Information that both groups had unrestricted access to telephones does not have a direct correlation to memory capability. Access to telephones affects the ability to make calls but it's irrelevant to memory retention of the call's timing.

(E) The amount of time each group received to receive instructions might have a slight impact. If Group B received instructions later than Group A, that might have been a factor that could account for their higher number of lapses. But if they were provided the instructions at the same time, then this factor is ruled out affecting the comparison between the two groups. 

Analyzing these options, option (B) is the least helpful in establishing that the conclusion (one type of memory doesn't decline with age) is properly drawn. Any potential biases introduced by having the same researchers answering the calls would cloud the results, thus making it a vital factor to be dismissed to ensure the study's internal validity. Without this factor, we should be more confident in linking the observed memory retention directly to age.

input:
Prediction, the hallmark of the natural sciences, appears to have been made possible by reducing phenomena to mathematical expressions. Some social scientists also want the power to predict accurately and assume they ought to perform the same reduction. But this would be a mistake; it would neglect data that are not easily mathematized and thereby would only distort the social phenomena.
Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the argument?
(A)The social sciences do not have as much predictive power as the natural sciences.
(B)Mathematics plays a more important role in the natural sciences than it does in the social sciences.
(C)There is a need in the social sciences to improve the ability to predict.
(D)Phenomena in the social sciences should not be reduced to mathematical formulas.
(E)Prediction is responsible for the success of the natural sciences.
output: (D) Phenomena in the social sciences should not be reduced to mathematical formulas.

input:
Studies have shown that the more high-stress points a bridge has, the more likely it is to fracture eventually. This might lead one to expect fractures to develop at high-stress points. Surprisingly, however, fractures develop not at high-stress points but elsewhere on the bridge.
Which one of the following, if true, contributes most to an explanation of why bridges fracture elsewhere than at high-stress points?
(A)In many structures other than bridges, such as ship hulls and airplane bodies, fractures do not develop at high-stress points.
(B)Fractures do not develop at high-stress points, because bridges are reinforced at those points; however, stress is transferred to other points on the bridge where it causes fractures.
(C)In many structures, the process of fracturing often causes high-stress points to develop.
(D)Structures with no high-stress points can nonetheless have a high probability of fracturing.
(E)Improper bridge construction, e.g., low-quality welding or the use of inferior steel, often leads both to the development of high-stress points and to an increased probability of fracturing.
output:
The statement that "fractures do not develop at high-stress points, because bridges are reinforced at those points; however, stress is transferred to other points on the bridge where it causes fractures" (option B) contributes most to an explanation of why bridges fracture elsewhere than at high-stress points.

Here's an analysis of each option:

(A) This option does not provide a direct explanation for the phenomenon under discussion. Bridge fractures are specific to bridge structures, and this statement does not help us understand why high-stress points might not be the location of fractures.

(B) This option offers a plausible explanation. Even though the bridge is reinforced at high-stress points, it does not mean those parts won't fracture. It's possible that stress is redistributed throughout the bridge, leading to fractures at less obvious points.

(C) This statement implies that high-stress points cause fractures but does not address the issue of bridges fracturing at locations other than high-stress points.

(D) Although this option tells us that a lack of high-stress points is not a guarantee against fractures, this information is not directly connected to the problem under discussion about fractures forming outside high-stress points.

(E) This option discusses the quality of construction and its relation to fracturing and high-stress points. However, it does not specifically explain why the fractures occur elsewhere on the bridge.

Overall, option B provides the most logical explanation as to why bridges fracture at locations outside of high-stress points. It acknowledges that while the bridge may be designed to distribute stress and reinforce high-stress points, the transfer of stress throughout the bridge can still lead to fractures at other points.

Many people say that the press should not pry into the personal lives of private individuals. But the press has the right to publish any story of interest to the public unless that story is libelous. So, if a story about a private individual is not libelous, the press has an obligation to publish it, for such information is clearly of interest to the public.
The argument's reasoning is vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument presumes, without giving warrant, that
(A)the press can publish nonlibelous stories about private individuals without prying into their personal lives
(B)one's having a right to do something entails one's having an obligation to do it
(C)the publishing of information about the personal lives of private individuals cannot be libelous
(D)if one has an obligation to do something then one has a right to do it
(E)the press's right to publish always outweighs the individual's right not to be libeled
output:
The argument's reasoning is vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument presumes, without giving warrant, that (B) one's having a right to do something entails one's having an obligation to do it.

The reasoning in the text assumes a direct correlation between a person's right and their obligation to act on that right. However, the author doesn't support this claim with sufficient reasoning. Simply that individuals might enjoy such rights doesn't logically obligate them to exercise those rights.
