input:
Columnist: A government-owned water utility has received approval to collect an additional charge on water bills and to use that additional revenue to build a dam. A member of the legislature has proposed not building the dam but instead spending the extra money from water bills to build new roads.That proposal is unacceptable.
Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the columnist's judgment that the legislator's proposal is unacceptable?
(A)Customers of a utility have a right to know how the money they pay to the utility will be used.
(B)Money designated for projects that benefit an entire community should not be used for projects that benefit only some members of a community.
(C)An additional charge on water bills should not be used to fund a project that most of the utility's customers disapprove of.
(D)An additional charge on water bills should not be imposed unless it is approved by the legislature.
(E)A water utility should not collect an additional charge unless the money collected is used for water-related expenditures.
output:
To evaluate the columnist's stance on the legislator's proposal, let's analyze each option logically.

(A) Customers of a utility have a right to know how the money they pay to the utility will be used.
This principle focuses on transparency and allowing customers to understand how the money they pay is being utilized. Though it may provide a valid argument, it doesn't directly address the disagreement between building the dam or the roads.

(B) Money designated for projects that benefit an entire community should not be used for projects that benefit only some members of a community.
This principle deals with selecting projects that benefit the community as a whole rather than benefiting individual members or specific groups. While it has a direct connection to the columnist's argument since he supports building the dam, which possibly serves more than a limited group, this is not necessarily the primary reason that the columnist finds the proposal unacceptable.

(C) An additional charge on water bills should not be used to fund a project that most of the utility's customers disapprove of.
This principle is similar to (A), focusing on customer satisfaction. It might highlight a reason for being against the new proposal; however, it doesn't offer the strongest justification for the columnist's position, based primarily on the community's needs and benefits.

(D) An additional charge on water bills should not be imposed unless it's approved by the legislature.
This principle addresses the due process for legislating a new charge. While it's a valid consideration, it doesn't directly uphold the columnist's view about building the dam versus the proposed roads.

(E) A water utility should not collect an additional charge unless the money collected is used for water-related expenditures.
This principle aligns with the primary reason that the columnist finds the legislator's proposal unacceptable: using money from water bills to build roads might appear to divert from the utility's core purpose, which is water service.

Based on the analysis, Option (E) provides the strongest principle to justify the columnist's judgment that the legislator's proposal to spend additional money from water bills on building new roads, instead of a dam, is unacceptable.

During its caterpillar stage, the leopard magpie moth feeds on a plant called the Natal grass cycad and by so doing laces its body with macrozamin, a toxin that makes the moth highly unpalatable to would-be predators. Since the Natal grass cycad is now endangered and facing extinction, the leopard magpie moth is also in danger of extinction.
Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
(A)Feeding on the Natal grass cycad is the only means by which the leopard magpie moth can make itself highly unpalatable to predators.
(B)The leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators.
(C)Potential predators of the leopard magpie moth cannot determine from appearance alone whether a moth's body is laced with macrozamin.
(D)Leopard magpie moths are not able to locate Natal grass cycads unless those plants are abundant.
(E)None of the potential predators of the leopard magpie moth have developed a tolerance to macrozamin.
output:
The assumption required by the argument is (B) The leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators.

This assumption is necessary because the argument focuses on the relationship between the endangered Natal grass cycad and its butterfly-like pollinator, implying that the moth's ability to feed on this plant makes it unpalatable for predators. If the moth had the ability to escape or not be preyed upon by any potential predators due to its speed or agility, then the endangerment of the Natal grass cycad might not directly impact the moth's survival chances.

Because of underfunding, our military is inadequate, the infrastructures of our cities are decaying, and our highways are in disrepair. If homeowners used all their money to pay off their mortgages early, while refusing to pay for upkeep of their homes, this would not make them better off financially. The same goes for the country as a whole.
Which one of the following most accurately expresses the conclusion drawn in the citizen's argument?
(A)Homeowners should not pay off their mortgages early if they must neglect upkeep of their homes in order to do so.
(B)It does not make sense for the government to use the budget surplus to pay down the national debt.
(C)A homeowner's personal financial situation is analogous in relevant ways to the financial situation of a country's government.
(D)Because of underfunding, the government does not maintain adequate standards in the services it provides.
(E)Government leaders want to use the country's large budget surplus to pay down the national debt.
output:
The citizen's argument is trying to draw a comparison between the use of a budget surplus for national debt reduction and homeowners paying off their mortgages early instead of maintaining their homes. The conclusion drawn is that not paying for upkeep of a home and paying off a mortgage early, or the government using its budget surplus to reduce the national debt when investing in areas like military, infrastructure, and highways, would not be better off financially. Therefore, the most accurate expression of the conclusion is:

(A) Homeowners should not pay off their mortgages early if they must neglect upkeep of their homes in order to do so.

Peraski: Although driving gas-guzzling automobiles produces a greater level of pollution than driving smaller cars, those of us who drive smaller cars when we could use a bicycle cannot speak out against the use of gas guzzlers. We would be revealing our hypocrisy. Jackson: I acknowledge I could do better in this area. But, it would be worse not to speak out against greater sources of pollution just because I am being hypocritical.
The dialogue provides the most support for the claim that Peraski and Jackson disagree over whether
(A)driving a gas-guzzling automobile produces a greater level of pollution than driving a smaller car
(B)speaking out against the use of gas guzzlers despite driving in situations in which one could use a bicycle reveals hypocrisy
(C)driving even a small car when one could use a bicycle contributes to the level of pollution
(D)one should speak out against polluting even if doing so reveals one's own hypocrisy
(E)there is no moral difference between driving a gas guzzler and driving a smaller car
output:
The dialogue provides the most support for the claim that Peraski and Jackson disagree over the matter of option (B) speaking out against the use of gas guzzlers despite driving in situations in which one could use a bicycle reveals hypocrisy.

In the dialogue, Peraski believes that it wouldn't be hypocritical to drive a small car instead of using a bicycle and still advocate against gas guzzlers. Jackson, on the other hand, argues that the act of driving a smaller car when one could bicycle implies inconsistency between personal actions and values, which is problems. This prompts Jackson to voice that it would be worse not to speak out against bigger pollutants because remaining silent constitutes a greater hypocrisy. Essentially, both seem to differ on how blameworthy hypocrisy is in the given context and what actions to prioritize.

For a species of large abalone shellfish to develop from a species of smaller ones, they must spend less energy on finding food and avoiding predators, and more on competition in mating. So it is surprising that the fossil record shows that a species of large abalones developed from a smaller one only after otters' which prey on abalones, began to dominate the waters in which the abalones lived.
Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?
(A)Otters and abalones also compete for the same types of food and so are drawn to the same waters.
(B)The fossils that were studied showed the development of only one of the two species of large abalones known to exist.
(C)Otters also prey on the abalones* competitors for food and so indirectly make it easier for abalones to get food.
(D)Small abalone species tend to reproduce more rapidly than larger abalone species.
(E)Otters have a preference for large abalones over small ones and so prefer waters in which large abalones are found.
output:
To resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information provided, we need to find a statement that explains why large abalones developed from smaller ones despite the presence of otters, which are their predators.

(A) Since it's a competition for the same types of food, the presence of otters doesn't directly resolve the discrepancy.

(B) This statement only provides information about the incomplete fossil record, and not about the relationship between otters, larger abalones, and smaller ones.

(C) This statement suggests that otters not only prey on the larger abalones but also on their competitors for food. In doing so, they indirectly make it easier for abalones to find food, which could help in the development of larger abalones from smaller ones by reducing the competition for food.

(D) The reproduction rate of small abalone species doesn't directly explain why large ones developed from smaller ones despite otters' presence.

(E) In the presence of otter preference for large abalones, it might seem like a contradiction to the given question.

The best option to resolve the discrepancy is (C), as it explains how the presence of otters can actually lead to the development of larger abalones, by decreasing the competition for food among abalone species.

input:
Some managers think that the best way to maximize employee performance is to institute stiff competition among employees. However, in situations where one competitor is perceived to be clearly superior, other competitors become anxious and doubt their own ability to perform. Thus, stiff competition can undermine the result it was intended to achieve.
The conclusion of the argument can be properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?
(A)Those who are perceived to be clearly superior almost always win.
(B)The winner of a competition is often the competitor who exerts the most effort.
(C)When competitors perceive the competition as winnable, their overall performance generally improves.
(D)Doubting one's own ability to perform can decrease one's overall performance.
(E)Competitors who work to undermine the confidence of other participants often do better in competitions.
output:
In order to properly draw the conclusion that stiff competition can undermine the result it was intended to achieve, the assumption needed here would be that the overall well-being and performance of employees are negatively impacted when their confidence is undermined.

The correct option that fits this scenario, and thus supports the conclusion, is:

(D) Doubting one's own ability to perform can decrease one's overall performance.

Justification:

The passage suggests that excessive competition, particularly when a "superior" competitor exists, leads to participant anxiety and doubts about their own ability to perform. Therefore, we need an assumption that directly supports these negative effects. Choice (D) aligns with this by asserting that actually questioning one's capabilities ("Doubting one's own ability to perform") can negatively impact self-efficacy and overall performance. Other options touch on various aspects of competition and may not necessarily support the conclusion. For example, (A) only addresses the outcome of superior competitors and (C) refers to performance changes depending on perceived likelihood of success - neither directly confirming that self-doubt leads to decreased performance.

input:
Creating a database of all the plant species in the scientific record has proved to be no easy task. For centuries, botanists have been collecting and naming plants without realizing that many were in fact already named. And by using DNA analysis, botanists have shown that varieties of plants long thought to belong to the same species actually belong to different species.
Of the following claims, which one can most justifiably be rejected on the basis of the statements above?
(A)Most of the duplicates and omissions among plant names in the scientific record have yet to be cleared up.
(B)An accurate database of all the plant species in the scientific record can serve as an aid to botanists in their work.
(C)Duplicates and omissions in the scientific record also occur in fields other than botany.
(D)Botanists have no techniques for determining whether distinct plant species have been given distinct names.
(E)A person who consults the scientific record looking under only one of a plant's names may miss available information about that plant.
output:
Based on the statements provided, we can examine each claim and determine if they can be justifiably rejected:

(A) Most of the duplicates and omissions among plant names in the scientific record have yet to be cleared up. - This statement can be supported by the information given, as it mentions that botanists are still discovering duplicates and omissions in the scientific record.

(B) An accurate database of all the plant species in the scientific record can serve as an aid to botanists in their work. - This statement can also be supported by the information, as fixing the issues with duplicates and omissions in plant names would improve the usefulness of such a database.

(C) Duplicates and omissions in the scientific record also occur in fields other than botany. - Since this statement is not specific to botany, there's no assurance or evidence given to counter it. Therefore, it can be justifiably rejected based on the given information.

(D) Botanists have no techniques for determining whether distinct plant species have been given distinct names. - This statement can be rejected as well. The information given implies that botanists are using DNA analysis to distinguish between species, which counters the claim that they lack techniques to differentiate between them.

(E) A person who consults the scientific record looking under only one of a plant's names may miss available information about that plant. - This statement can be justified since the text mentions the existence of duplicates and omissions in the scientific record.

In conclusion, claim (C) and claim (D) are the most justifiably rejected based on the statements provided.

A year ago several regional hospitals attempted to reduce the number of patient injuries resulting from staff errors by implementing a plan to systematically record all such errors. The incidence of these injuries has substantially decreased at these hospitals since then. Clearly, the knowledge that their errors were being carefully monitored made the hospitals* staffs much more meticulous in carrying out their patient-care duties.
Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
(A)Before the plan was implemented the hospitals already had a policy of thoroughly investigating any staff error that causes life-threatening injury to a patient.
(B)The incidence of patient injuries at a regional hospital that did not participate in the plan also decreased over the year in question.
(C)The plan did not call for the recording of staff errors that could have caused patient injuries but did not.
(D)The decrease in the incidence of the injuries did not begin at any hospital until the staff there became aware that the records were being closely analyzed.
(E)Under the plan, the hospitals' staff members who were found to have made errors that caused injuries to patients received only reprimands for their first errors.
output:
(D)The decrease in the incidence of the injuries did not begin at any hospital until the staff there became aware that the records were being closely analyzed.

This option strengthens the argument by implying that knowing their errors were being monitored triggered a change in behavior among hospital staff, leading to a decrease in patient injuries due to staff errors. The other answer choices either do not directly support the original claim that staff meticulousness through the system of recording errors helped decrease injuries or provide alternate causative factors for the reduction in injuries.

In a national park located on an island, a herd of moose was increasing in number and threatening to destroy species of native plants. Wolves were introduced to the island to reduce the herd and thereby prevent destruction of the vegetation. Although the wolves prospered, the moose herd continued to grow.
Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the failure of the strategy involving wolves?
(A)The presence of wolves in an area tends to discourage other predators from moving into the area.
(B)Attempts to control moose populations in other national parks by introducing predators have also been unsuccessful.
(C)Wolves often kill moose weakened by diseases that probably would have spread to other moose.
(D)Healthy moose generally consume more vegetation than do those that are diseased or injured.
(E)Moose that are too old to breed are just as likely to die of natural causes as of attack by wolves.
output:
(B) Attempts to control moose populations in other national parks by introducing predators have also been unsuccessful.

This option suggests that the strategy of introducing wolves to control the moose population isn't as effective as originally assumed. If this strategy has failed in other areas as well, it strongly indicates that the problem may not be purely predator-prey dynamics, but rather considerations like habitat, food sources, or other ecological factors that weren't sufficiently addressed in the initial plan.

(C)trades on the use of a term in one sense in a premise and in a different sense in the conclusion
(D)draws a conclusion about how the world actually is on the basis of claims about how it should be
(E)infers that because a set of things has acertain property, each member of that set has the property
output:
(D) draws a conclusion about how the world actually is on the basis of claims about how it should be

The argument infers a conclusion about how existing laws should operate based on a theoretical purpose (contributing to people's happiness) instead of relying solely on empirical evidence. It implies a normative claim, emphasizing how laws should be evaluated rather than how they truly are.

In order for life to exist on the recently discovered planet P23, there must be water on the planets surface. But there is no water on P23's surface, so there is no life on planet P23.
The pattern of reasoning in the argument above is most similar to that in which one of the following arguments?
(A)A company must have efficient employees to be successful. And if a company's employees are knowledgeable and hardworking, then they are probably efficient. Thus, in order for a company to be successful, it must have knowledgeable and hardworking employees.
(B)The fact that the suspect was flustered when questioned by the police might be a result of the suspect's surprise at being questioned. But if it is, the probability that the suspect is guilty is very low. Thus, the fact that the suspect was flustered is not necessarily a sign that the suspect is guilty.
(C)Oil companies are not buying new drilling equipment. But if they were planning on increasing their drilling, they would be buying new drilling equipment. Thus, oil companies are not planning on increasing their drilling.
(D)The price of real estate in a particular town is increasing. And if the town's economy were improving, the price of real estate there would increase. Thus, the town's economy is improving.
(E)The exports of a particular nation have recently decreased. But whenever that nation's exports decrease, its trade deficit increases. Thus, the nation's trade deficit has recently increased.
output:
The pattern of reasoning in the given argument can be matched with argument (C): Oil companies are not buying new drilling equipment. But if they were planning on increasing their drilling, they would be buying new drilling equipment. Thus, oil companies are not planning on increasing their drilling.

This argument follows the same pattern because it refers to a situation where an observation (not buying new drilling equipment) is connected with the lack of potential for an event (increasing drilling). It then analogously applies this observation to a different context (P23's condition) to deduce a conclusion (no life) similarly as no water implies no life on the planet. The central element in both arguments is the absence of an essential component leading to the impossibility of a certain outcome.

Airport administrator: According to the latest figures, less than 1 commercial flight in 2 million strays off course while landing,a number low enough to allow runways to be built closer together without a significant increase in risk. Opponents of closer runways claim that the number is closer to 1 in 20,000, but this figure is based on a partial review of air traffic control tapes and so is relatively unreliable compared to the other figure, which is based on a thorough study of the flight reports required of pilots for all commercial flights.
Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the airport administrator's argument?
(A)The argument presumes, without providing justification, that building runways closer together will encourage pilots to be more cautious while landing.
(B)The argument overlooks the fact that those who make mistakes are often unreliable sources of information about those mistakes.
(C)The argument questions the integrity of those who are opposed to allowing runways to be built closer together.
(D)The argument presumes, without providing justification, that the air traffic control tapes studied do not provide accurate information concerning specific flights.
(E)The argument infers from a lack of conclusive evidence supporting the higher number's accuracy that it must be inaccurate.
output:
The flaw in the airport administrator's argument lies in option (E): The argument infers from a lack of conclusive evidence supporting the higher number's accuracy that it must be inaccurate. 

The administrator relies on the more reliable study of flight reports, and the opponents of closer runways provide a less-reliable partial review. However, merely because there's a difference in data sources does not necessarily validate the first set of statistics over the second. In regards to aviation safety, both stray incidents are low and further data reviews or investigations may be necessary to solidify the accuracy of both sides' figures.

input:
In deep temperate lakes, water temperatures vary according to depth. In winter, the coldest water is at the top; in summer, at the bottom. The changes in temperature distribution,or "turnover," occur in fall and late winter- Lake trout will be found, as a rule, in the coldest water. So, if anglers seek lake trout in deep temperate lakes while these lakes are partially iced over in late winter, they will do best to eschew the lake trout's summer haunts and fish instead in a shallow bay or close to the surface off a rocky point.
Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
(A)The ease with which lake trout can be caught by anglers varies with the time of year and the water temperature.
(B)Cold water is denser, and therefore heavier,than relatively warmer water.
(C)Lake txout are found exclusively in deep temperate lakes.
(D)Lake trout do not alter their feeding habits from one part of the year to another.
(E)In deep temperate lakes that have ice residues on the surface, late-winter "turnover" has not yet occurred.
output:
The argument depends on the assumption (B) Cold water is denser, and therefore heavier, than relatively warmer water.

This assumption is crucial because the water turnover in late winter causes the coldest water to come to the surface, making it colder water where lake trout are found during this time. Knowing that cold water is denser helps to understand why it is found at the bottom in the summer but at the surface in the winter. The argument relies on this correlation between water density and its position during seasonal changes to suggest that anglers should target shallow, cold waters to find lake trout.

Liang: Watching movies in which violence is portrayed as an appropriate way to resolve problems increases levels of aggression in viewers. Therefore, children's access to these movies should be restricted. Sarah: Watching a drama whose characters are violent allows the audience to vicariously experience the emotions associated with aggression and thus be purged of them. Hence, the access by mature audiences to such forms of entertainment should not be restricted.
The dialogue provides the most support for inferring that Liang and Sarah agree with each other that
(A)people who experience an emotion vicariously are likely to purge themselves of that emotion
(B)the members of a mature audience are unlikely to believe that violence is sometimes an appropriate way to resolve problems
(C)if violence in certain movies causes violence in viewers, access to those movies should be restricted
(D)the effects of dramatic depictions of violenceon audiences are at least partially understood
(E)children are more likely than adults to be attracted to dramas involving characters who behave violently
output:
Step 1: Analyze the claim made by Liang
Liang suggests that watching movies with violence increases aggression levels in viewers and supports the idea that children's access to such movies should be restricted.

Step 2: Analyze the claim made by Sarah
Sarah argues that watching violent dramas allows audiences to vicariously experience and potentially purge emotions associated with aggression. She also states that access for mature audiences should not be restricted.

Step 3: Evaluate the options
Now, we will look at each option and compare it to the claims made by Liang and Sarah to see which option can be supported by both.

(A) People who experience an emotion vicariously are likely to purge themselves of that emotion - This option aligns with Sarah's claim that watching violent dramas can allow viewers to purged of the emotions associated with aggression.

(B) The members of a mature audience are unlikely to believe that violence is sometimes an appropriate way to resolve problems - This option involves beliefs about violence which neither Liang nor Sarah directly discuss.

(C) If violence in certain movies causes violence in viewers, access to those movies should be restricted - Liang supports this statement, but Sarah disagrees with her suggestion of restriction.

(D) The effects of dramatic depictions of violence on audiences are at least partially understood - Neither Liang nor Sarah seems to focus specifically on understanding the effects of violence, but rather on the potential consequences or feelings aroused by such depictions.

(E) Children are more likely than adults to be attracted to dramas involving characters who behave violently - This option isn't directly supported by either Liang or Sarah.

Step 4: Conclusion
After analyzing the claims made by Liang and Sarah, the option that is most supported by both of them is:

(A) People who experience an emotion vicariously are likely to purge themselves of that emotion

Which one of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the politician's argument?
(A)Opposing higher taxes is not a factor contributing to good leadership.
(B)Being opposed to higher taxes is not a sufficient condition for good leadership.
(C)Thompson has questionable opinions concerning important issues other than taxes.
(D)All of the past leaders who supported highertaxes performed their jobs adequately.
(E)All of the past leaders who supported highertaxes were hardworking.
output:
The politician's argument is that Thompson's opposition to higher taxes makes them a better leader than other candidates. To cast doubt on this argument, we need to find a statement that challenges the connection between Thompson's opposition to higher taxes and their ability to perform as a good leader.

(A) This option casts doubt on the politician's argument by stating that opposing higher taxes doesn't contribute to good leadership. This breaks the link between Thompson's position on taxes and their ability to lead well.

(B) This option also undermines the politician's argument by stating that merely being opposed to higher taxes is not enough for one to be a good leader. It suggests that there are other factors to consider when determining a candidate's suitability as a leader.

(C) This option casts doubt on Thompson's overall suitability as a nation's leader by pointing to other potential issues with Thompson's opinions. However, it doesn't directly dispute the connection between Thompson's stance on taxes and their leadership abilities.

(D) This option states that past leaders who supported higher taxes performed their jobs adequately. While this information could be relevant in assessing the overall performance of leaders who support higher taxes, it doesn't directly challenge the connection between Thompson's opposition to higher taxes and their leadership qualities.

(E) This option focuses on the hardworking nature of leaders who support higher taxes. Like (D), this information may be relevant, but it doesn't directly challenge the connection between Thompson's position on taxes and their leadership ability.

Among these options, (A) carries the most weight in casting doubt on the politician's argument, because it directly challenges the assumption that opposing higher taxes equates to being a better leader. The politician's argument is based on the belief that Thompson's opposition to higher taxes would make them a better leader. If opposing higher taxes doesn't contribute to good leadership, the connection between Thompson's tax stance and their abilities as a man in lead becomes questionable.

Garza responds to Patterson by doing which one of the following?
(A)arguing that the body of evidence to which Patterson appeals is insufficient for Patterson's purposes
(B)offering evidence to challenge the truth of the premise of Patterson's argument
(C)presenting a counterexample to the general conclusion drawn in Patterson's argument
(D)presenting an argument analogous to Patterson's argument to reveal a potential flaw in Patterson's reasoning
(E)using Patterson's evidence to draw a conclusionin consistent with the conclusion drawn in Patterson's argument
output:
(A) arguing that the body of evidence to which Patterson appeals is insufficient for Patterson's purposes

Garza challenges Patterson's argument by pointing out that the abundance of bone artifacts in the Upper Paleolithic context may not provide a comprehensive representation of the variety and prevalence of materials used for musical instruments in earlier periods, suggesting that the evidence may not be enough to accurately determine that music first arose during the Upper Paleolithic.

input:
No occupation should be subject to a licensing requirement unless incompetence in the performance of tasks normally carried out within that occupation poses a plausible threat to human health or safety.
The principle stated above, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in which one of the following arguments?
(A)Because some of the duties that police officer scarry out have no connection to human health or safety, police officers should not be subject to a licensing requirement.
(B)Because there are no realistic circumstances in which poor work by an interior designer poses a danger to human beings, interior designers should not be subject to a licensing requirement.
(C)Because hospital administrators routinely make decisions that affect the health of hundreds of people, hospital administrators should be subject to a licensing requirement.
(D)Because hair stylists regularly use substances that can pose a threat to human health if handled improperly, hair stylists should be subject to a licensing requirement.
(E)Because tattoo artists who do not maintain strict sanitation pose a serious threat to human health, tattoo artists should be subject to a licensing requirement.
output:
Step 1: Identify the principle stated in the question.
The principle is that a licensing requirement for an occupation is only justified if incompetence in the performance of tasks within that occupation poses a plausible threat to human health or safety.

Step 2: Analyze each argument based on the principle.

(A) This argument contradicts the principle. The duties performed by police officers do play a vital role in public safety and public health.

(B) This argument aligns with the principle. Interior designers' work, as suggested, does not pose a direct threat to human health or safety.

(C) This argument is incorrect. Even though hospital administrators make decisions affecting numerous people's health, they are not directly involved in carrying out tasks that pose a danger to human health or safety.

(D) This argument contradicts the principle. As hair stylists handle substances that pose a potential threat to human health if mishandled, a licensing requirement might be justified according to the principle.

(E) This argument aligns with the principle. Tattoo artists who fail to maintain proper sanitation pose a direct threat to human health, which supports the need for a licensing requirement.

Step 3: Choose the argument most consistent with the principle.

(B) Because there are no realistic circumstances in which poor work by an interior designer poses a danger to human beings, interior designers should not be subject to a licensing requirement.

This answer best aligns with the principle that a licensing requirement is only necessary if an occupation's tasks pose a threat to human health or safety.

Most of the new cars that Regis Motors sold last year were purchased by residents of Blomenville. Regis Motors sold more new cars last year than it did in any previous year. Still, most new cars purchased by Blomenville residents last year were not purchased from Regis Motors.
If the statements above are true, which one of the following must also be true?
(A)Regis Motors sold more new cars to residents of Blomenville last year than they had in any previous year.
(B)The total number of new cars purchased by residents of Blomenville was greater last year than it was in any previous year.
(C)A car retailer other than Regis Motors sold the most new cars to residents of Blomenville last year,
(D)The number of new cars purchased last year by residents of Blomenville is greater than the number of new cars sold by Regis Motors.
(E)Regis Motors' share of the new car market in Blomenville last year increased over its share the year before.
output:
Let's break down the given statements and assess the truth of each option:

1. Regis Motors sold more new cars last year than any previous year.
2. Most new cars purchased by Blomenville residents last year were not purchased from Regis Motors.

Now, let's analyze each option:

A) Regis Motors sold more new cars to residents of Blomenville last year than they had in any previous year.
- This statement cannot be proved with the given information. We only know that Regis sold more cars overall than any previous year, not specifically driven by Blomenville sales.

B) The total number of new cars purchased by residents of Blomenville was greater last year than it was in any previous year.
- Since the majority of cars were not from Regis Motors, it's likely that they purchased cars from other retailers. This option is not necessarily true.

C) A car retailer other than Regis Motors sold the most new cars to residents of Blomenville last year,
- Based on statement 2, this option could be true as most cars were not sold by Regis.

D) The number of new cars purchased last year by residents of Blomenville is greater than the number of new cars sold by Regis Motors.
- Again, we cannot prove this statement true with the given information. We are only certain that Regis sold more cars overall.

E) Regis Motors' share of the new car market in Blomenville last year increased over its share the year before.
- It's evident that Regis' market share has decreased since most new cars purchased by Blomenville residents were from sources other than Regis Motors.

Based on the analysis of all options, the only statement that must be true is option (C). A car retailer other than Regis Motors sold the most new cars to residents of Blomenville last year.

Editorial: Teenagers tend to wake up around 8:00 A.M., the time when they stop releasing melatonin, and are sleepy if made to wake up earlier. Since sleepiness can impair driving ability, car accidents involving teenagers driving to school could be reduced if the school day began later than 8:00 A.M. Indeed, when the schedule for Granville's high school was changed so that school began at 8:30 A.M. rather than earlier, the overall number of car accidents involving teenage drivers in Granville declined.
Which one of the following, if true, provides the most support for the argument in the editorial?
(A)Teenagers start releasing melatonin later at night and stop releasing it later in the morning than do young children.

The cool, dense water in ocean depths takes centuries to mix with the warmer water near the surface, so any carbon dioxide pumped deep into oceans would be trapped there for centuries.
Which one of the following is an assumption that the oceanographer's argument requires?
(A)Carbon dioxide will dissolve much more thoroughly if it is pumped into cold water than it will if it is pumped into warmer water.
(B)Evaporation of warmer ocean water near an ocean's surface does not generally release into the atmosphere large amounts of the carbon dioxide dissolved in the evaporating water.
(C)Carbon dioxide dissolved in cool, dense waterin ocean depths will not escape back into Earth's atmosphere a long time before the water in which that carbon dioxide is dissolved mixes with warmer water near the surface.
(D)It is the density of the water in the ocean depths that plays the main role in the trapping of the carbon dioxide.
(E)Carbon dioxide should be pumped into ocean depths to reduce the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere only if the carbon dioxide pumped into ocean depths would be trapped there for hundreds of years.
output:
The assumption the oceanographer's argument requires is (C) "Carbon dioxide dissolved in cool, dense water in ocean depths will not escape back into Earth's atmosphere a long time before the water in which that carbon dioxide is dissolved mixes with warmer water near the surface."

This assumption is necessary for the proposed method of pumping carbon dioxide into the ocean to work as described. If the dissolved carbon dioxide were to escape into the atmosphere before the water mixes with warmer waters near the surface, then it would not be trapped in the ocean as intended, thus reducing the potential benefit of this method in terms of long-term carbon dioxide capture.

Community organizer: Before last year's community cleanup, only 77 of the local residents signed up to participate, but then well over 100 actually participated. This year, 85 residents have signed up to participate. Since our community cleanup will be a success if we have at least 100 participants, we can be confident that this year's cleanup will be a success.
The reasoning in the community organizer's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument
(A)generalizes about the outcome of an event based on a single observation of a similar situation
(B)takes for granted that people who participated in last year's cleanup will participate this year
(C)confuses a condition that is required for an outcome with one that is sufficient for that outcome
(D)overlooks the possibility that the cleanup will attract participants who are not residents in the community
(E)defines a term in such a way as to ensure that whatever the outcome, it will be considered a positive outcome
output:
The reasoning in the community organizer's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument (C)confuses a condition that is required for an outcome with one that is sufficient for that outcome.

Explanation:
The organizer assumes that having 85 residents signed up to participate in this year's cleanup guarantees over 100 participants. This is mistaken, as just having more people sign up doesn't ensure that all those who signed up will show up (which is the condition needed for the event to be a success). The correct condition should be based on the actual number of participants, rather than just those who signed up.

input:
Psychologist: In our study, participants who were offered the opportunity to purchase a coffee mug were not willing to pay more than $5. If, however, they were given a very similar mug and asked immediately afterwards how much they would be willing to sell it for, most of them held out for more than $5.
Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy described above?
(A)A person's assessment of the value of an object depends on his or her evaluation of the inherent properties of the object.
(B)People are usually unable to judge the value of an object when they have possessed it for a long period of time.
(C)The amount a person is willing to spend on an object is determined by the amount that object sold for in the past.
(D)People tend to value an object that they do no town less than they value a very similar object that they already own.
(E)People are more likely to undervalue objects they have been given than objects they have purchased.
output:
The observed discrepancy arises from the statement that participants were willing to pay no more than $5 for the coffee mug (when merely adopting the role of buyer) but then were willing to accept payment above this price for a very similar mug (when adopting the selling role). The most plausibly parsimonious explanation for this difference – given the options provided – is (D) "People tend to value an object that they own less than a very similar object that they don't own."

In the context of this explanation, ownership increases a person's appreciation of an item, and they value their owned items more because they now have a personal attachment to them. When the mug is just sitting across the table as a potential purchase, they can only see an external value, which is capped at their maximum willingness to pay. When they own it (even temporarily), their attachment or emotional value towards the mug increases, causing them to demand more to part with it.

Ecologist: Before finding a mate, male starlings decorate their nests with fragments of aromatic plants rich in compounds known to kill parasitic insects. Since these parasites are potentially harmful to nestlings, some researchers have hypothesized that the function of these decorations is nestling protection. However, males cease to incorporate such greenery once egg laying starts, which suggests instead that the function of the decorations is to attract females.
Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the support for the ecologist's conclusion?
(A)Adult starlings are able to defend themselves against parasitic insects.
(B)Male starlings do not decorate their nests in areas with unusually small populations of parasitic insects.
(C)Nestlings grow faster in nests that incorporate aromatic plants than in nests that do not.
(D)Male starlings tend to decorate their nests with a greater number of aromatic plants when a caged female is positioned adjacent to the nest.
(E)The compounds in the aromatic plants used by the male starlings to decorate their nests are harmless to nestlings.
output:
D) Male starlings tend to decorate their nests with a greater number of aromatic plants when a caged female is positioned adjacent to the nest.

This option strengthens the support for the ecologist's conclusion that the function of the decorations is to attract females because it provides evidence that male starlings increase their use of aromatic plants when the presence of a female is nearby, suggesting they are more likely using the decorations to entice the female. This directly supports the idea that such display behaviors are related to courtship and mate attraction, rather than to parasite protection.

(A)Conditions that create a feeling of security also encourage risk taking.
(B)Problems created by humans require human-created solutions.
(C)Technical fixes are inevitably temporary.
(D)Technical fixes cannot discourage risk-taking behavior.
(E)The longer a problem goes unresolved, the worse it becomes.
output:
The engineer's argument can most reasonably be interpreted as invoking (A) Conditions that create a feeling of security also encourage risk taking. 

The engineer's argument revolves around the idea that removing an obstacle in the road, which creates a sense of security for drivers, results in them taking more risks. Similarly, implementing a technical fix for slowing down global warming (like blocking a portion of the sun's rays) would lead to a perceived sense of security, thus encouraging increased carbon dioxide emissions, which, ironically, may cause further global warming. This argument clearly points to the connection between security/comfort and risk-taking behavior, as mentioned in choice (A). The other options do not adequately capture the central idea conveyed by the engineer.

Although some animals exhibit a mild skin reaction to urushiol, an oil produced by plants such as poison oak and poison ivy, it appears that only humans develop painful rashes from touching it. In fact, wood rats even use branches from the poison oak plant to build their nests. Therefore, urushiol probably did not evolve in these plants as a chemical defense.
Which one of the following, if true, adds the most support for the conclusion of the argument?
(A)Wood rats build their nests using dead, brittle branches, not live ones.
(B)A number of different animals use poison oakand poison ivy as food sources.
(C)It is common for plants to defend themselves by producing chemical substances.
(D)In approximately 85 percent of the human population, very small amounts of urushiol can cause a rash.
(E)Poison oak and poison ivy grow particularly well in places where humans have altered natural forest ecosystems.
output:
To find the most support for the conclusion that urushiol probably did not evolve in these plants as a chemical defense, we need to consider why these plants might produce urushiol and lack such defense mechanisms. The conclusion implies that since these plants don't cause painful rashes in humans and animals use them for nest building, perhaps other evolutionary benefits prompted them to produce urushiol.

(A) This option supports the idea that wood rats use live branches, which might be a support to the argument about ant defense mechanisms or biotic factors playing a role in nest building. But it does not specifically explain the evolutionary role of urushiol.

(B) This option shows that other animals benefit from consuming the plants, indicating that urushiol aids in protecting these plants from these consumers. Since it doesn't harm the plants directly, this seems to be a more likely evolutionary benefit, supporting the argument's conclusion.

(C) While it's true that plants use chemical substances for defense, this statement doesn't provide insight into why poison oak and poison ivy specifically don't use urushiol for resilience.

(D) This information only emphasizes how urushiol affects humans, but it doesn't bring anything to explain the evolution of urushiol.

(E) This option points to humans' interaction with the environment, but again, it doesn't explain urushiol's potential role in the plants' evolution.

Hence, option B seems to add the most support for the conclusion that urushiol likely evolved in poison oak and poison ivy plants for reasons other than chemical defense against animals like humans and wood rats.

(A)Evaluation of legislation should take into account actual results, not intentions alone.
(B)The wealthier members of a community should not have undue influence on its governance.
(C)A community' s tax laws and zoning regulations should apply equally to all individuals within selected areas.
(D)Legislation that is not to anyone's benefit should not be commended.
(E)Laws that give advantage to the well-to-do can also benefit society as a whole.

The principle that most helps to justify the politician's criticism is (A) Evaluation of legislation should take into account actual results, not intentions alone. This principle emphasizes the importance of considering the real-life impacts and outcomes of a policy or legislation, rather than solely focusing on the initial intentions behind it.

The case provided shows that the legislation aimed at renovating and revitalizing aging urban areas, initially intended to help long-term residents, ended up benefiting wealthier professionals instead. Because of this shift, the politician criticizes the legislation, highlighting the importance of evaluating the actual effects rather than the initial goals. This criticism is best supported by recognizing that assessment of policy should consider the ultimate results on the community.

Thus, for the most part, only government-sponsored research investigates agricultural techniques that do not use commercial products.
Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the farmer's argument?
(A)The government sponsors at least some investigations of agricultural techniques that are considered likely to solve agricultural problems and do not use commercial products.
(B)For almost any agricultural problem, there is at least one agricultural technique that does not use commercial products but that would solve that agricultural problem.
(C)Investigations of agricultural techniques are rarely sponsored by individuals or by any entity other than private for-profit corporations or the government.
(D)Most if not all investigations of agricultural techniques that use commercial products are sponsored by private for-profit corporations.
(E)Most if not all government-sponsored agricultural research investigates agricultural techniques that do not use commercial products.
output:
Let's break down the farmer’s argument:

|Premise 1|The agricultural techniques like crop rotation that do not use commercial products can solve agricultural issues as efficiently as techniques like pesticide application that use commercial products.|

|Premise 2|No private for-profit corporation will fund research that no commercial product could be developed from, hence government research explores alternatives that do not use commercial products.|

|Conclusion|Only government-sponsored research will investigate non-commercial agricultural techniques.|

Now, let's see the options to determine which strengthens the farmer's argument:

(A)If the government sponsors investigations of alternative agricultural techniques, it supports the farmer's argument that the government's exclusive role in researching non-commercial alternatives strengthens the farmer's perspective. Therefore, (A) strengthens the farmer's argument.

(B)Tells that an alternative is always available for every problem but doesn't specifically relate to the influence of government-sponsored research on studies about non-commercial agricultural techniques. It doesn't directly strengthen the farmer's argument.

(C)Suggests private corporations are usually not interested in research sponsorship, but it doesn't confirm that government sponsored investigations are the sole workhorse for non-commercial research. This does not strengthen the farmer's argument.

(D)Implies that more commercial product research has commercial backing, but it doesn't confirm that the government is the dominant sponsor for non-commercial agricultural techniques research. It fails to strengthen the farmer's position.

(E)Affirms that the government examines only non-commercial techniques. This fits perfectly with the farmer's conclusion but instead of strengthening the argument, it restates it.

By process of elimination, the answer is (A). It supports the farmer's argument that government-sponsored research is most likely to explore non-commercial agricultural techniques.

(B)relies on a sample that is likely to be unrepresentative

(E)argues that a certain action ought to be undertaken merely on the grounds that it would be popular

(C) overlooks the possibility that student preference is not the only factor to be considered when it comes to deciding which food vendor the university should hire.

However, this argument overlooks potentially significant factors other than student preference that might also influence the decision, such as the quality of the food, the pricing, the availability of food options, the environmental impact, the contractual obligations between the university and current and potential vendors, and so on. These factors could provide valid reasons for not rehiring Hall Dining Services even if the majority of students prefer it.

input:
On average, cats fed canned cat food eat fewer ounces of food per day than do cats fed dry cat food; the canned food contains more calories per ounce than does the dry food. Nonetheless, feeding a cat canned cat food typically costs more per day than does feeding it dry cat food.
Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
(A)On average, cats fed canned cat food eat more calories per day than do cats fed dry cat food.
(B)Typically, cats are fed either canned cat food or dry cat food, or both.
(C)How much it costs to feed a cat a given kind of food depends only on how many calories per ounce that food contains.
(D)On average, it costs no less to feed a cat that eats fewer ounces of food per day than it does to feed a cat that eats more ounces of food per day.
(E)Canned cat food typically costs more per ounce than does dry cat food.
output:
Let's analyze the information provided before selecting the most strongly supported statement:

1. Cats fed canned cat food eat fewer ounces of food per day than cats fed dry cat food.
2. Canned cat food contains more calories per ounce than dry food.
3. Feeding a cat canned cat food typically costs more per day than feeding it dry cat food.

Now, let's analyze the answer options:

(A) This statement is incorrect because, according to the information, cats fed canned food eat fewer ounces but have more calories per ounce.

(B) The information doesn't explicitly state whether cats are fed only one type of food or both. We cannot infer this from the given data.

(C) The given information states that cats fed canned food typically cost more despite eating fewer ounces, so it doesn't seem that the cost depends only on the calories per ounce.

(D) This statement is strongly supported because the information provided says that despite canned cat food having more calories per ounce, the overall cost of feeding a cat with this food is still higher, taking into account the lower quantity of food eaten. In other words, it does cost no less to feed a cat that eats more (dry) food as it does to feed a cat that eats less (canned) food.

(E) This statement is incorrect because, based on the information, canned food typically costs more per day than dry food, not per ounce.

The most strongly supported statement is (D) On average, it costs no less to feed a cat that eats fewer ounces of food per day than it does to feed a cat that eats more ounces of food per day.

The foundation doing the reconstruction took extraordinary care to return the church to its original form. (A)An eighteenth-century baroque organ cannot adequately produce much of the organ music now played in church services and concerts.
(B)The organ originally designed for the church had some features that modem organs lack.
(C)The donation for rebuilding the originaleighteenth-century baroque organ was designated for that purpose alone.
(D)By the time the church was destroyed in World War II, the eighteenth-century baroque organ had been modified several times.
(E)In the eighteenth century, the organ playedan important role in church services at the Frauenkirche.
output:
(A)An eighteenth-century baroque organ cannot adequately produce much of the organ music now played in church services and concerts.

This statement helps to resolve the puzzle by explaining the foundation's decision to build a modern organ instead of rebuilding the original eighteenth-century baroque organ. Since the original organ cannot adequately produce the organ music that is now popular in church services and concerts, the foundation may have chosen to prioritize the preferences and needs of present-day audiences and musicians by installing a modem organ that could serve the church better today.

There is a notable exception, however: it should never reduce import taxes if one or more of its domestic industries would be significantly harmed by the added competition. Conclusion: The government should not reduce taxes on textile imports.
Which one of the following is a statement from which the conclusion can be properly drawn using the principle?
(A)Reducing taxes on textile imports would notf inancially benefit many consumers in the domestic economy.
(B)Reducing taxes on textile imports would financially benefit some consumers in the domestic economy but would not benefit the domestic textile industry.
(C)The domestic textile industry faces significant competition in many of its export markets.
(D)The domestic textile industry and consumers in the domestic economy would benefit less from reductions in taxes on textile imports than they would from other measures.
(E)The added competition produced by any reduction of taxes on imports would significantly harm the domestic textile industry.
output:
Based on the provided principle, the conclusion that "The government should not reduce taxes on textile imports" can be drawn using the statement: 
(E) The added competition produced by any reduction of taxes on imports would significantly harm the domestic textile industry.

This is because the principle explicitly mentions that a government should not reduce import taxes if one or more of its domestic industries would be significantly harmed by the added competition. Statement (E) directly points out that the domestic textile industry would be significantly harmed by reduced taxes on textile imports, leading to the conclusion of not reducing these taxes.

Option (C) contradicts the implications, as understanding technical information tends to assist jurors rather than hinder the assessment. It claims that being able to visit such sites distracts us, keeping us from doing our best work. But offices that have windows or are nicely decorated can be highly distracting too, and no one claims that people do their best work in an undecorated, windowless room.
Which one of the following arguments is most similar in its reasoning to the employee's argument?
(A)Some people advocate moderation in all things. But different people react differently to certain substances, so what counts as a moderate amount of, say, caffeine for you might be too much for me. So to talk about moderation is to fail to take into account people's basic biological differences.
(B)Activists are calling for an electronic device to be banned, for research has shown that prolonged exposure to the device while it is in use causes cancer in laboratory animals. But most chemicals probably cause cancer when administered in very high doses, yet no one would argue that we should ban all these chemicals for that reason.
(C)Acme expects that approximately 1,000 of its employees will retire over the next year. No one would claim that Acme does not need a work force as large as its present one. So Acme will need to hire approximately 1,000 people over the next year.
(D)In many creative writing classes, aspiring writers are told that if the characters they create are not engaging, their novels and stories will not sell. But this does not mean that engaging characters guarantee a sale-publishers and agents often reject manuscripts that emphasize character to the exclusion of other elements.
(E)In the movie industry, a film's success is judged in terms of its profit relative to its cost. This is misguided, because under this criterion an expensive movie that sells just as many tickets as a lower-budget movie would be less successful than the lower-budget movie, which is clearly counter intuitive.
output: The employee's argument can be compared to option (B). The employee argues that restricting internet access solely for non-work-related websites can be counterproductive because it reduces productivity and doesn't account for the varying work styles of employees. Likewise, option (B) discusses the argument against banning electronic devices due to their possible cancer-causing effects in high doses, pointing out that the solution is not to ban all substances potentially causing cancer.

At Tromen University this semester, some students taking French Literature 205 are also taking Biology 218. Every student taking Biology 218 at Tromen is a biology major. Therefore, some of the students taking French Literature 205 are not French-literature majors.
The conclusion drawn above follows logically if which one of the following is assumed to be true at Tromen University?
(A)French Literature 205 is a required course forFrench-literature majors.
(B)Only biology majors are allowed to take Biology 218.
(C)There are more biology majors than there are French-literature majors.
(D)There are more French-literature majors than there are biology majors.
(E)It is not possible to major in both biology and French literature.
output:
To solve this problem, let's analyze the information given and understand the conclusion to be drawn.

Given information:
1. Some students taking French Literature 205 are also taking Biology 218.
2. Every student taking Biology 218 at Tromen is a biology major.

Conclusion:
Some of the students taking French Literature 205 are not French-literature majors.

To arrive at this conclusion, we need an assumption that explains why these French Literature 205 students with an overlapping enrollment in Biology 218 are not French-literature majors.

Let's analyze the options:

(A) This assumption does not explain why these students taking French Literature 205 and Biology 218 are not French-literature majors.

(B) This assumption helps explain that students taking Biology 218 must be biology majors, but it doesn't confirm that students taking French Literature 205 are not French-literature majors.

(C) This assumption may explain that there are some biology students taking French Literature 205, but it does not necessarily prove that they aren't French-literature majors.

(D) This statement implies that there are students enrolled in French Literature 205 not majoring in French Literature. This is because they have an overlapping enrollment in Biology 218 (which is only for biology majors), hence, some of the students taking French Literature 205 are not French-literature majors.

(E) This statement presumes that students cannot major in both biology and French literature, in which case they cannot enroll in both French Literature 205 and Biology 218, but it contradicts the given information.

So, the reasoned assumption that best supports the conclusion is option (D) "There are more French-literature majors than there are biology majors."

(A)Any book worthy of serious study is a literary classic.
(B)A book is a literary classic only if it is worthy of serious study.
(C)There are no literary classics worthy of serious study.
(D)Some books worthy of serious study do not reveal anything significant about the human condition.
(E)Some books that reveal something significant about the human condition are not literary classics.
output:
Step 1: Understanding the given statements
The critic mentioned two main points:
1. To be a literary classic, a book must reveal something significant about the human condition.
2. Nothing unworthy of serious study can reveal anything significant about the human condition.

Step 2: Analyzing the answer choices
We need to determine which statement must be true based on the given information.

A) Any book worthy of serious study is a literary classic.
- This statement cannot be determined as a necessity based on the two given statements. It does not follow the original premise.

B) A book is a literary classic only if it is worthy of serious study.
- This statement cannot be determined as necessary because worthy of serious study is the condition for something significant about the human condition, not only for a literary classic. 

C) There are no literary classics worthy of serious study.
- This statement cannot be determined as necessary based on the given information since the given statements don't address the existence or non-existence of literary classics worthy of serious study.

D) Some books worthy of serious study do not reveal anything significant about the human condition.
- This statement directly contradicts the second statement mentioned initially, which says nothing unworthy of serious study reveals anything significant about the human condition. So this option is not true.

E) Some books that reveal something significant about the human condition are not literary classics.
- This statement is in line with the first given statement, as a literary classic requires revealing something significant about the human condition. However, it could also imply that the author might not have reached other criteria or widespread popularity or acclaim needed to be considered a classic.

Conclusion:
The statement that must be true, based on the given information, is (E): Some books that reveal something significant about the human condition are not literary classics. This should occur in compliance with the necessary conditions of a literary classic – this is a logical conclusion based on the given statements.

input:
Scientists once believed that the oversized head, long hind legs, and tiny forelimbs that characterized Tyrannosaurus rex developed in order to accommodate the great size and weight of this prehistoric predator. However, this belief must now be abandoned. The nearly complete skeleton of an earlier dinosaur has recently been discovered. This specimen had the characteristic T. rex features but was one-fifth the size and one-hundredth the weight.
The answer to which one of the following questions would most help in evaluating the argument?
(A)Was the ratio of the head size of the recently discovered dinosaur to its body size the same as that for T. rexl
(B)At what stage in its life did the recently discovered dinosaur die?
(C)Was T. rex the largest and heaviest prehistoric predator?
(D)Was the species to which the recently discovered dinosaur belonged related to T. rex?
(E)Did the recently discovered dinosaur prey on species as large as those that T. rex preyed on?
output:
D) Was the species to which the recently discovered dinosaur belonged related to T. rex?

Evaluating the argument, the most crucial factor is if this recently discovered dinosaur's species is related to T. rex. If they are closely related, it could explain why they evolved comparable physical features (i.e., giant heads, long hind legs, and tiny forelimbs) despite their vast differences in size and weight. If they are not closely related, it would strengthen the argument against the initial belief that these features developed due to the great size and weight of T. rex. The other options are less relevant to the argument at hand.

YXK is currently the television network with the highest overall number of viewers. Among YXK's programs, Bliss has the highest numbers of viewers. So Bliss currently has more viewers than any other program on television.
The flawed reasoning exhibited by the argument above is most similar to that exhibited by which one of the following?
(A)Soccer players suffer more leg injuries, on average, than any other athletes at this university. Linda Wilson has suffered more leg injuries than any other soccer player at this university. Thus, Linda Wilson is the athlete at this university who has suffered the most leg injuries.
(B)Teachers at our school have won more teaching awards, on average, than teachers at any other school in this city. Janna Patel is the teacher who has won the most awards in the city. So Janna Patel is the best teacher at our school.
(C)The Olson Motor Company manufactures the three best-selling automobile models in the country. The Decade is the Olson Motor Company's best-selling model. Thus the Decade is the best-selling model in the country.
(D)In this city the highest-paid police officer earns more than the highest-paid firefighter, and the lowest-paid police officer earns more than the lowest-paid firefighter. So in this city police officers earn more, on average, than firefighters do.
(E)Falling Fast is the film that is currently earning the most at the box office in the country. The most successful film in the country is typically the one that is showing in the most theaters. So Falling Fast is probably the film that is currently showing in the most theaters.
output:
The flawed reasoning in the given argument about YXK and Bliss is that it assumes that because Bliss, a program on YXK, has more viewers than any other program, it must have more viewers than any other program on television. This reasoning is similar to option (D).

Option (D) states: "In this city, the highest-paid police officer earns more than the highest-paid firefighter, and the lowest-paid police officer earns more than the lowest-paid firefighter. Thus, in this city police officers earn more, on average, than firefighters do." The flaw in this reasoning is assuming that because individual police officers earn more than individual firefighters, police officers earn more on average than firefighters overall, without accounting for factors like job market conditions that could affect the earnings of both roles.

In contrast, options (A) and (E) do not share this specific flawed reasoning. Option (A) incorrectly assumes that more injuries in a specific sport equates to more injuries overall for an athlete not mentioned in the average. In option (E), while it assumes Falling Fast showing in the most theaters based on being the highest earner, this line of reasoning does not explicitly state that it is more successful than all other films, only in terms of earnings.

input:
A contract between two parties is valid only if one party accepts a legitimate offer from the other; an offer is not legitimate if someone in the position of the party to whom it was made would reasonably believe the offer to be made in jest.
The principle stated above, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in which one of the following arguments?
(A)Joe made a legitimate offer to buy Sandy's car and Sandy has not rejected the offer. Thus, there was a valid contract.
(B)Kenta accepted Gus's offer to buy a shipmentof goods, but Gus, unknown to Kenta, made the offer in jest. Thus, the contract was not valid.
(C)Frank's offer to buy Mindy's business from her was legitimate. Thus, if Mindy is a reasonable person, she will accept the offer.
(D)Hai's offer to sell artworks to Lea was made in such a way that no one in Lea's position would have reasonably believed it to be made in jest. Thus, if Lea accepts the offer, they have a valid contract.
(E)The only offer that Sal made to Veronica was not a legitimate one. Thus, regardless of whether Sal made the offer in jest, there is no valid contract between them.
output:
To determine which argument best aligns with the given principle, we should examine the principle step-by-step and evaluate it against the options presented.

Step 1: Identify the key points in the given principle.
- A contract is valid only if an offer is accepted.
- An offer is legitimate only if the recipient would not reasonably believe it to be made in jest.

Step 2: Evaluate each argument based on the key points from Step 1.

(A) Joe made a legitimate offer to buy Sandy's car and Sandy has not rejected the offer. Thus, there was a valid contract.
- This argument is valid according to the principle. Joe made a legitimate offer, and Sandy did not reject it, making the contract valid.

(B) Kenta accepted Gus's offer to buy a shipment of goods, but Gus, unknown to Kenta, made the offer in jest. Thus, the contract was not valid.
- This argument aligns with the principle, as Gus's offer was made in jest, making it not a legitimate offer. Consequently, the contract was not valid due to the legitimacy of the offer being questionable.

(C) Frank's offer to buy Mindy's business from her was legitimate. Thus, if Mindy is a reasonable person, she will accept the offer.
- This argument does not fully align with the principle, as it focuses on Mindy's decision to accept the offer rather than examining the legitimacy of the offer itself.

(D) Hai's offer to sell artworks to Lea was made in such a way that no one in Lea's position would have reasonably believed it to be made in jest. Thus, if Lea accepts the offer, they have a valid contract.
- This argument aligns with the principle, as Hai's offer was made without being perceived as a jest, establishing a legitimate offer. If Lea accepts it, a valid contract will be formed accordingly.

(E) The only offer that Sal made to Veronica was not a legitimate one. Thus, regardless of whether Sal made the offer in jest, there is no valid contract between them.
- This argument partially aligns with the principle as it acknowledges that the offer is not legitimate. However, it does not consider the possibility that Sal might have made the offer in jest.

Conclusion:
Based on the principle given, arguments (A) and (D) justify the reasoning most accurately. Argument (B) also aligns with the principle but focuses on a different aspect of contract formation where the offer was made in jest. Arguments (C) and (E) are less aligned with the principle because they do not address the central aspect directly related to a party's reasonable perception of the offer.

input:
Scientist: A small group of islands near Australia is inhabited by several species of iguana; closely related species also exist in the Americas, but nowhere else. The islands in question formed long after the fragmentation of Gondwana, the ancient supercontinent that included present-day South America and Australia. Thus, these species' progenitors must have rafted on floating debris across the Pacific Ocean from the Americas.
Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the scientist's argument?
(A)A number of animal species that inhabit the islands are not found in the Americas.
(B)Genetic analysis indicates that the iguana species on the islands are different in several respects from those found in the Americas.
(C)Documented cases of iguanas rafting long distances between land masses are uncommon.
(D)Fossils of iguana species closely related to those that inhabit the islands have been found in Australia.
(E)The lineages of numerous plant and animal species found in Australia or in South America date back to a period prior to the fragmentation of Gondwana.
output:
The task is to identify the option that weakens the scientist's argument. The scientist argues that iguana species on a small group of islands near Australia should have originated in the Americas, assuming these species did not evolve on the islands themselves. The scientist's reasoning is based on the fact that the islands formed after the fragmentation of Gondwana, which included present-day South America and Australia.

Option D: "Fossils of iguana species closely related to those that inhabit the islands have been found in Australia." most weakens the scientist's argument. If there are fossils of iguana species closely related to those on the islands in Australia, it suggests that the progenitors of the island species could have originated in that same supercontinent, rather than the Americas as previously assumed. This evidence contradicts the theory that they must have rafted over from the Americas and breaks down the scientist's argument.

input:
A recent archaeological find in what was once the ancient kingdom of Macedonia contains the remains of the largest tomb ever found in the region. It must be the tomb of Alexander the Great since he was the greatest Macedonian in history, and so would have had the largest tomb. After all, he conquered an empire that stretched from Greece to much of Asia, though it collapsed after his death.
Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the scientist argument?
(A)Takes for granted that greatness can be attained only by military conquest
(B)Takes for granted that the largest tomb found so far must be the largest that was built
(C)Does not show how the recently discovered tomb compares with other tombs from the same period that have been found in other regions
(D)Fails to evaluate the significance of the fact that Alexander empire did not survive his death
(E)Takes for granted that archaeologists can determine the size of the tomb from its remains
output:
(C) Does not show how the recently discovered tomb compares with other tombs from the same period that have been found in other regions.

This statement weakens the scientist's argument by pointing out that the scientist does not consider other possible examples of large tombs from the same era in the region or beyond. Without this comparison, it's difficult to confidently assert that the recently discovered tomb in Macedonia is indeed the largest ever found. Other larger tombs could exist, which would demonstrate that the size of a tomb does not necessarily correlate with the greatness or historical significance of the individual it belongs to.
